Bug.Summery: JSP Debugger can't find source path on Generic WebLogic Server 9.0

Lines.Line: 1. Create a Generic WLS 9.0 server, making sure to modify the setDomainEnv.cmd
script according to bug 103593 in order to enable debug mode.
2. Create a JSP named "testjsp.jsp" (per bug 103874) in the WebContent directory
of a Dynamic Web Project with the Generic WLS 9.0 as the target server.
3. Add a scriptlet such as <% out.println("hello"); %> to the JSP.
4. Set a breakpoint on the line containing the scriptlet.
5. In the Project Explorer, right-click on the JSP and choose "Debug As > Debug
6. Choose to switch to Debug Perspective when the dialog appears.

Bug.WithStack:
IBuild 20050719 [Tue, 19 Jul 2005 -- 06:39 (-0400)]
Repro: 1. Create a Generic WLS 9.0 server, making sure to modify the setDomainEnv.cmd script according to bug 103593 in order to enable debug mode. 2. Create a JSP named "testjsp.jsp" (per bug 103874) in the WebContent directory of a Dynamic Web Project with the Generic WLS 9.0 as the target server. 3. Add a scriptlet such as <% out.println("hello"); %> to the JSP. 4. Set a breakpoint on the line containing the scriptlet. 5. In the Project Explorer, right-click on the JSP and choose "Debug As > Debug on Server". 6. Choose to switch to Debug Perspective when the dialog appears.
Result: The debugger hits the breakpoint and the editor opens with a "Source not found." message. Expected: The debugger hits the breakpoint, the editor opens to "testjsp.jsp" and indicates the instruction at which the debugger has stopped.
Note: The same scenario works on Tomcat 5.5. Gorkem: I'm going to look into this a bit more now but do you think this could be due to differences between TomcatSourcePathComputerDelegate and GenericServerSourcePathComputerDelegate? It's most likely that the WebContent folder isn't listed as a FolderSourceContainer. The default container for a Java project only provides the Java build paths, and WebContent is normally not on the build path. Looks like this is related to logic in the generic server framework level; assigning to Gorkem per email. I have done some testing with Jonas and Geronimo and they are working as expected. The problem exists with WLS only. I now think this is not related to GenericServerSourcePathComputerDelegate missing something. This is not related to server adapter returning deficient source containers. I have done some tracing, WLS prepends jsp_servlet to the generated JSP servlets and as a result source lookup lofigic searches for jsp_servlet\my.jsp for /my.jsp in the source containers and naturally fails. I am not sure on how to proceed further in the server adapter to overcome this I am assigning to jst.jsp please let me know if I can do any help.
Sending back to Gorkem. The JSP component's neither involved in setting up source containers nor paths.
Did you mean WLS is prepending "jsp_servlet." to the classnames it generates (in which case the Generic support might need to support such mangling) or is it writing the wrong source filename or path into the .class file? Gorkem: assign to me let me know if I can help. Thomas just fixed the same problem for our custom WLS adapter; the fix involved the following:
-associating the launchConfigurationType with a custom source locator that extends the JavaSourceLookupDirector -this custom lookup director contributes a custom ISourceLookupParticipant that extends the JavaSourceLookupParticipant and includes logic to check for and strip off "jsp_servlet\\" from the source name
Although a similar solution could potentially be employed for the generic adapter problem, there are some issues:
-the generic launchConfigurationTypes are not app-server specific so binding to a source locator that embeds app server-specific logic is a bad solution within the generic server context -modifying the generic server framework to allow server types to contribute custom source lookup logic would be fairly involved and, even if appropriate for the generic server framework, is out-of-scope for the 1.0 timeframe.
I'm going to differ a decision on this one to you, Gorkem, but my current thinking is that we do one of the following:
-Bind a custom source locator to the external launch config type that includes WLS-specific logic; not a pretty solution but it may be tolerable if WLS ends up being the only generic adapter requiring special treatement (or there are a small number of other cases that can be added to the custom locator as needed) -Draw the line between generic and custom adapter support on this item (at least for 1.0): only so much functionality can be expected from generic adapters and, for WLS, this is the exactly the type of feature that motivates a custom adapter. Created attachment 31199 Patch for org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core
Patch that incorporates Thomas Yip's fix for the WLS JSP debugging src lookup problem: binds a custom extension of JavaSourceLookupDirector (performs WLS-specific modifications to src names) to the "external" launch configuration type (currently used just by the WLS generic servers)
I haven't been able to verify this patch. I used it to enhance org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core_1.0.0.jar
plugin.properties plugin.xml org\eclipse\jst\server\generic\core\internal\GenericSourceLookupDirector$JspSourceLookupParticipant.class org\eclipse\jst\server\generic\core\internal\GenericSourceLookupDirector.class
and replaced with it, the old one.
However when debugging the JSP, I get the old error Source not found Edit Source Lookup Path.
Ivan, in doing this "hand patch" ... did you restart with -clean?
BTW, I think there was a a related patch needed in JSP plugin. see bug 103874.
Ivan: just tried things w/ the jar you sent along and it's not working, however, it does work for me when I launch Eclipse with my workspace version of org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core (the one I used to create the patch)
Regarding the fix to org.eclipse.jst.jsp.ui: you should only need that if your JSP is nested inside another folder inside WebContent, however, I think you were having issues w/ a non-nested JSP.
I'll dig around a bit more... Update with 1.5.1 build (200607272136): This repros with the new generic WLS 9.2 server adapter, as well as the generic WLS 9.0 adapter. Thanks for the update, Beck.
Gorkem, sending this along your way since I'd like your input on the required changes here (see comment #9). The current fix requires non-ideal changes to the generic framework (i.e. necessitates binding a WLS-specific source locator to the external launch configuration type).
Until it is feasible to allow generic server types to contribute source locators, I think it is OK in this context to resolve this as "won't fix": only so much functionality is possible with generic servers and, given the special requirements for WLS in this area, full JSP debugging with the generic WLS adapter is not supported.
Note: I had further follow-up coversations with Ivan and he was able to resolve the issue successfully with the patches. Reassigning this one to Danny since he has some good thoughts about an alternative approach that would fix the issue without impacting the core generic server code. The alternative approach is to programmaticly add sourceLookupParticipant in a custom server behavior class, instead of bind Weblogic custom source lookup director to generic launchConfigurationType:
(1) have the generic class ExternalServerBehaviour expose a protected method: protected void setupSourceLocator(ILaunch launch) {} which subclass can override and add additional sourceLookupParticipant.
(2) Weblogic server adapter will have its own ServerBehaviourDelegate, GenericWeblogicServerBehaviour, which provides a custom sourceLookupParticipant strip off "jsp_servlet\\" from the source name during source lookup.
Created attachment 56435 Patch for org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core Created attachment 56436 Patch for org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.weblogic
Patch for org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.weblogic, with a custom Weblogic serverBehaviorDelegate and JspSourceLookupParticipant Rob, can you review the patch above and what is the process to get it into the build? yep, I'll give it a look and, assuming everything looks good, commit it HEAD generic.core patch looks OK. I have committed generic.core patch to the HEAD. just let me know when you are ready to release. Things look good, Danny; thanks for looking into this one.
Gorkem, I've committed the generic.weblogic changes (along with a small change to GenericServer that fixes the getModuleRootURL() logic for ports different than 80; was adding the numeric value for ':' to the port in that case)
So, go ahead and release the changes to both generic.core and generic.weblogic when you're ready released Closing as part of mass query to clean up old resolved bugs in untargetted milestones. This is pretty important patch, however it has incorrect version number. Actually the bug is solved in 2.x series...
Is there any possibility to backport it to 1.5? No plans to backport that to 1.5 since the 1.5.x branches are are effectively shutdown now. Future work on the the WLS adapters is now being done via the downloadable versions; if/when possible, you should upgrade to WTP 2.0 and install the downloadable WLS server adapters.

Bug.Summery: [performance framework] global.php href has absolute pathname instead of relative
Bug.WithStack:
The generated performance graph directory global.php's href has absolute pathname it should have been relative to be more portable.
If I try the performance results to share, I had to change the href of global.php, this is not the case with other php's.
Below is the example of global.php. Eg: href="D:\depot\dev\src910\wli\eclipse\performance- graph/wlirelengwin/com.bea.wli.ide.mapper.ui.tests.performance.Open_XQ.testOpenX Q().html#CPU Time"
Should be: href="wlirelengwin/com.bea.wli.ide.mapper.ui.tests.performance.Open_XQ.testOpenX Q().html#CPU Time" Created attachment 25006 Global.php This was fixed a while ago.

Bug.Summery: [URI resolver] URI resolver should not chain resolution results/remove pre/post normalization phases

Lines.Line: 1. Currently the URI resolver framework chains resolvers, calling every resolver
in the chain and passing in the result from the previous resolver. For example,
if I defined extension resolvers A, B, and C, the framework will run A, send the
result of A to B, run B, send the result of B to C, run C, and send the result
of C back to the caller. This strategy does not allow consistentcy amoung
resolvers. When a resolver is called, it may get the input as specified by the
caller or it may get a resolved result from another resolver. Of more
importance, from what I have seen extension resolvers typlically stand alone,
meaning the result of one resolver is of no interest to another resolver.
I suggest the resolver chaining mechanism be changed to return the first result
located. This solves the first problem mentioned above and should have a
positive performance impact as unnecessary additional resolvers will no longer
2. The URI resolver framework currently has two stages: prenormalization and
postnormalization. These two stages pose a problem for extension resolvers the
specify a priority. A postnormalization resolver with a high priority will
always be run after a prenormalization resolver with a low priority. The type of
input a resolver requires should not dictate the order in which it is run.
2. changes the framework chaining to return the first result returned from a
3. changes the framework to expect a null return value from resolvers that
Lawrence, your original comment said "...that the normalize method be called to
create both prenormalized and post normalized inputs..". If this wasn't a typo
I strongly disagree. For taglibs the input must be passed to the extension
Nitin, I guess my comment was unclear. What I am suggesting is that the input be
normalized before a resolver is called but that the original input be maintained

Bug.WithStack:
There are two related parts to this enhancement request.
1. Currently the URI resolver framework chains resolvers, calling every resolver in the chain and passing in the result from the previous resolver. For example, if I defined extension resolvers A, B, and C, the framework will run A, send the result of A to B, run B, send the result of B to C, run C, and send the result of C back to the caller. This strategy does not allow consistentcy amoung resolvers. When a resolver is called, it may get the input as specified by the caller or it may get a resolved result from another resolver. Of more importance, from what I have seen extension resolvers typlically stand alone, meaning the result of one resolver is of no interest to another resolver.
I suggest the resolver chaining mechanism be changed to return the first result located. This solves the first problem mentioned above and should have a positive performance impact as unnecessary additional resolvers will no longer be run.
2. The URI resolver framework currently has two stages: prenormalization and postnormalization. These two stages pose a problem for extension resolvers the specify a priority. A postnormalization resolver with a high priority will always be run after a prenormalization resolver with a low priority. The type of input a resolver requires should not dictate the order in which it is run.
I suggest that the normalize method be called to create both prenormalized and post normalized inputs that can then be passed to the resolvers depending on the type of input they require. A secondary requirement of this change is that extension resolvers return a common result when they are unable to resolve the resource. For simplicity I will suggest that they return null. This is open for discussion. Created attachment 25012 Patch that removes pre/postnormalization stages
This patch: 1. removes the pre/post normalization stages 2. changes the framework chaining to return the first result returned from a resolver 3. changes the framework to expect a null return value from resolvers that cannot resolve a given URI Lawrence, your original comment said "...that the normalize method be called to create both prenormalized and post normalized inputs..". If this wasn't a typo I strongly disagree. For taglibs the input must be passed to the extension as-is or lookups can fail. Nitin, I guess my comment was unclear. What I am suggesting is that the input be normalized before a resolver is called but that the original input be maintained as well. So we'll have,
String input; String normalizedInput;
A resolver will either receive the input or the normalizedInput depending on whether it is declared as a prenormalization or postnormalization resolver.
In your case, the taglibs will receive the input "as-is".
Bug.WithOutStack:
There are two related parts to this enhancement request.
1. Currently the URI resolver framework chains resolvers, calling every resolver in the chain and passing in the result from the previous resolver. For example, if I defined extension resolvers A, B, and C, the framework will run A, send the result of A to B, run B, send the result of B to C, run C, and send the result of C back to the caller. This strategy does not allow consistentcy amoung resolvers. When a resolver is called, it may get the input as specified by the caller or it may get a resolved result from another resolver. Of more importance, from what I have seen extension resolvers typlically stand alone, meaning the result of one resolver is of no interest to another resolver.
I suggest the resolver chaining mechanism be changed to return the first result located. This solves the first problem mentioned above and should have a positive performance impact as unnecessary additional resolvers will no longer be run.
2. The URI resolver framework currently has two stages: prenormalization and postnormalization. These two stages pose a problem for extension resolvers the specify a priority. A postnormalization resolver with a high priority will always be run after a prenormalization resolver with a low priority. The type of input a resolver requires should not dictate the order in which it is run.
I suggest that the normalize method be called to create both prenormalized and post normalized inputs that can then be passed to the resolvers depending on the type of input they require. A secondary requirement of this change is that extension resolvers return a common result when they are unable to resolve the resource. For simplicity I will suggest that they return null. This is open for discussion. Created attachment 25012 Patch that removes pre/postnormalization stages
This patch: 1. removes the pre/post normalization stages 2. changes the framework chaining to return the first result returned from a resolver 3. changes the framework to expect a null return value from resolvers that cannot resolve a given URI Lawrence, your original comment said "...that the normalize method be called to create both prenormalized and post normalized inputs..". If this wasn't a typo I strongly disagree. For taglibs the input must be passed to the extension as-is or lookups can fail. Nitin, I guess my comment was unclear. What I am suggesting is that the input be normalized before a resolver is called but that the original input be maintained as well. So we'll have,
String input; String normalizedInput;
A resolver will either receive the input or the normalizedInput depending on whether it is declared as a prenormalization or postnormalization resolver.
In your case, the taglibs will receive the input "as-is".

Bug.Summery: TVT31:tct 306 "Name" is in English in the New Cascading Style Sheet Wizard

Lines.Line: 1. Go to File ->New ->Other ->Web and select CSS
3. End the file name with .css then press the Next button.
==> "Name" is in English in the New Cascading Style Sheet Wizard
The string does not appear to be translated for zh_TW.

Bug.WithStack:
OS : RHEL 3.1 Severity 3 Build date: 20050718 Blocking: NO Language: CHT Bitmap Location: 306_26001450.gif Tester Name: Ivory Chang
Problem Description: "Name" is in English in the New Cascading Style Sheet Wizard Re-create Procedure: 1. Go to File ->New ->Other ->Web and select CSS 2. Click the Next button 3. End the file name with .css then press the Next button. ==> "Name" is in English in the New Cascading Style Sheet Wizard Created attachment 25009 306_26001450.gif The string does not appear to be translated for zh_TW.
Look in: org.eclipse.wst.css.ui.nl1 org.eclipse.wst.css.ui.internal.CSSUIPluginResources_zh_TW.properties
the following needs to be translated: NewCSSTemplatesWizardPage_2=Name
Oh ... who should owner be if "needs translation" is the issue?
Or should this be closed as "worksforme"?
During TVT (i.e. before the eclipse open source project owns the translations) we typically provide the pointer to the string as you have done and close the bug as invalid because there is no error in the component at that time. If a string makes it all the way through the process untranslated or with an improper translation and a bug is created after the component has taken ownership of the translations (post IBM contribution to the eclipse foundation of the translations) the bug remains open and is resolved as fixed once an updated set of fragments are available. Typically in this case it is left in the affected component and the owner is set to Cam.
Excellent, thanks Steve.
Please re-open if you find more is needed from us. Verifying and closing on behalf of reporter.

Typically in this case it is left in the affected component and the owner is set to Cam.

Please re-open if you find more is needed from us. Verifying and closing on behalf of reporter.

merge those tests into one, or into several that are prefixed by the name of the
e.g. new Symptom DB, import Symptom DB
If keeping the test suites as multiple suites => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_new
If merging the test suite into a single suite => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor
4. If a test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, and the
test cases are used by more than one component, then choose a bugzilla component
4.1 Create a test suite for that owner component.
4.2 For the other bugzilla components, create a test suite and nest the owner
test suite inside to indicate that this test suite depends on the owner test suite.
5. In the case when a test suite contains both shared tests and tests that
are not shared, choose an owner bugzilla component for the common tests and
create a test suite for it. Create a separate test suite for the tests that are
not shared. The not-shared suite should nest the common test suite inside to
show that it depends on the common test suite.

2. Open the Test Perspective. Open the test suite by double-clicking on it.
Change the "Name" and "Description" to reflect the new name.

4. Open the ResourceContents file in Notepad. (Double-click in WinZip.)

7. Open up the "AllTests.testsuite" that is in the grandparent directory. Go to

Bug.WithStack:
This is a defect for all of the test suites owned by the Monitoring Project.
Refactor the TPTP test suite so that the name of the test suite contains the name of the bugzilla component because this will make tracking test status easier. When the test reports are generated, the names of the bugzilla components must be in the report instead of descriptive names. The list of tests in the report can then be compared to the list of bugzilla components and any missing test cases will be identified by the Project lead.
Paul recommended that we refactor at the directory level as well for containment and use the bugzilla component as an additional name space.
If the test suite contains several functions, you can either use the bugzilla component name as the name of the test suite or use the bugzilla component as a prefix, e.g. Platform.Communication_AC and Platform.Communication_RAC to show test results for both the new agent controller and the existing agent controller.
Migrating existing test suites: 1. When the existing test suite contains tests for a single bugzilla component, just rename the test suite. e.g. "Java Profiler" -> Platform.Agents.JVMPI 2. For cases where the test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, but the test cases for each component are not shared, then split that test suite into several, each named according to their bugzilla component. 3. If multiple test suites provide tests for the same bugzilla component, merge those tests into one, or into several that are prefixed by the name of the bugzilla component as explained above. e.g. new Symptom DB, import Symptom DB If keeping the test suites as multiple suites => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_new Symptom DB, Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_import Symptom DB If merging the test suite into a single suite => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor 4. If a test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, and the test cases are used by more than one component, then choose a bugzilla component to own the test suite. 4.1 Create a test suite for that owner component. 4.2 For the other bugzilla components, create a test suite and nest the owner test suite inside to indicate that this test suite depends on the owner test suite. 5. In the case when a test suite contains both shared tests and tests that are not shared, choose an owner bugzilla component for the common tests and create a test suite for it. Create a separate test suite for the tests that are not shared. The not-shared suite should nest the common test suite inside to show that it depends on the common test suite.
Note that the refactoring operation may be a problem since there is an outstanding defect for renaming test suites (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=83087). -Rename test suites- 1. Rename the actual ".testsuite" file. (Open the "Navigator" view, right click, "Rename", change the name from "ABC.testsuite" to "BugzillaComponent.testsuite"). 2. Open the Test Perspective. Open the test suite by double-clicking on it. Change the "Name" and "Description" to reflect the new name. 3. Open the .testsuite file with WinZip (right-click, Open With, System Editor > Winzip). 4. Open the ResourceContents file in Notepad. (Double-click in WinZip.) 5. Rename "ABC" to "BugzillaComponent" on the "name" attribute of the "behavior" element from ABC_behavior to BugzillaComponent_behavior. 6. Update the the zip file with the ResourceContents test suite inside of Eclipse (hit F5 to refresh). 7. Open up the "AllTests.testsuite" that is in the grandparent directory. Go to the Behavior tab, remove the invocation to the old test suite (ABC - invocation). Insert > Invocation > browse to the new test suite. Save the editor. 8. In the cases where there are other test suites that link to ABC.testsuite, those also have to be changed, using the same technique as in #7. 9. Delete the ABC.testsuite from CVS, add the BugzillaComponent.testsuite into CVS, and update the AllTests.testsuite in CVS.
-Moving test suites- 1. Create a brand new test suite. (Follow the instructions in README.txt.) http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/test-results/platform/org.eclipse.hyades.tests/README.txt?rev=HEAD&cvsroot=TPTP_Project&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup
2. Manually copy the test cases from the old test suite into the new test suite. 3. Follow #7, #8, and #9.
-Splitting test suites or merging test suites- If you need to split up tests amongst test suites, then create several new test suites and add the appropriate tests. Similarly for merging test suites, create a single new test suite and add the test cases from the old test suites into the new.
The following Monitoring Tools Project component testsuites have been refactored:
Monitor.Analysis Monitor.Execution Monitor.UI Monitor.UI.GLARules Monitor.UI.SDBEditor Monitor.Agents has been refactored All Monitoring Tools testsuites have been refactored. Testsuite renaming completed but Monitoring testsuites need to be moved to the Monitoring Procect in CVS. All Monitoring Tools testsuites that were in the org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases project under platform have been moved to the org.eclpise.tptp.monitoring.tests project under monitor in CVS. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

are not shared, choose an owner bugzilla component for the common tests and
create a test suite for it. Create a separate test suite for the tests that are
not shared. The not-shared suite should nest the common test suite inside to
show that it depends on the common test suite.
1. When the existing test suite contains tests for a single bugzilla
component, just rename the test suite.
2. For cases where the test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla
components, but the test cases for each component are not shared, then split
that test suite into several, each named according to their bugzilla component.
3. If multiple test suites provide tests for the same bugzilla component,
merge those tests into one, or into several that are prefixed by the name of the
e.g. new Symptom DB, import Symptom DB
If keeping the test suites as multiple suites => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_new
If merging the test suite into a single suite => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor
4. If a test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, and the
test cases are used by more than one component, then choose a bugzilla component
4.1 Create a test suite for that owner component.
4.2 For the other bugzilla components, create a test suite and nest the owner
test suite inside to indicate that this test suite depends on the owner test suite.
5. In the case when a test suite contains both shared tests and tests that
are not shared, choose an owner bugzilla component for the common tests and
create a test suite for it. Create a separate test suite for the tests that are
not shared. The not-shared suite should nest the common test suite inside to
show that it depends on the common test suite.

2. Open the Test Perspective. Open the test suite by double-clicking on it.
Change the "Name" and "Description" to reflect the new name.
3. Open the .testsuite file with WinZip (right-click, Open With, System Editor >
4. Open the ResourceContents file in Notepad. (Double-click in WinZip.)
5. Rename "ABC" to "BugzillaComponent" on the "name" attribute of the "behavior"

7. Open up the "AllTests.testsuite" that is in the grandparent directory. Go to

those also have to be changed, using the same technique as in #7.

Bug.WithStack:
This is a defect for all of the test suites owned by the Test Project.
Refactor the TPTP test suite so that the name of the test suite contains the name of the bugzilla component because this will make tracking test status easier. When the test reports are generated, the names of the bugzilla components must be in the report instead of descriptive names. The list of tests in the report can then be compared to the list of bugzilla components and any missing test cases will be identified by the Project lead.
Paul recommended that we refactor at the directory level as well for containment and use the bugzilla component as an additional name space.
If the test suite contains several functions, you can either use the bugzilla component name as the name of the test suite or use the bugzilla component as a prefix, e.g. Platform.Communication_AC and Platform.Communication_RAC to show test results for both the new agent controller and the existing agent controller.
Migrating existing test suites: 1. When the existing test suite contains tests for a single bugzilla component, just rename the test suite. e.g. "Java Profiler" -> Platform.Agents.JVMPI 2. For cases where the test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, but the test cases for each component are not shared, then split that test suite into several, each named according to their bugzilla component. 3. If multiple test suites provide tests for the same bugzilla component, merge those tests into one, or into several that are prefixed by the name of the bugzilla component as explained above. e.g. new Symptom DB, import Symptom DB If keeping the test suites as multiple suites => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_new Symptom DB, Monitor.UI.SDBEditor_import Symptom DB If merging the test suite into a single suite => Monitor.UI.SDBEditor 4. If a test suite contains tests for multiple bugzilla components, and the test cases are used by more than one component, then choose a bugzilla component to own the test suite. 4.1 Create a test suite for that owner component. 4.2 For the other bugzilla components, create a test suite and nest the owner test suite inside to indicate that this test suite depends on the owner test suite. 5. In the case when a test suite contains both shared tests and tests that are not shared, choose an owner bugzilla component for the common tests and create a test suite for it. Create a separate test suite for the tests that are not shared. The not-shared suite should nest the common test suite inside to show that it depends on the common test suite.
Note that the refactoring operation may be a problem since there is an outstanding defect for renaming test suites (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=83087). -Rename test suites- 1. Rename the actual ".testsuite" file. (Open the "Navigator" view, right click, "Rename", change the name from "ABC.testsuite" to "BugzillaComponent.testsuite"). 2. Open the Test Perspective. Open the test suite by double-clicking on it. Change the "Name" and "Description" to reflect the new name. 3. Open the .testsuite file with WinZip (right-click, Open With, System Editor > Winzip). 4. Open the ResourceContents file in Notepad. (Double-click in WinZip.) 5. Rename "ABC" to "BugzillaComponent" on the "name" attribute of the "behavior" element from ABC_behavior to BugzillaComponent_behavior. 6. Update the the zip file with the ResourceContents test suite inside of Eclipse (hit F5 to refresh). 7. Open up the "AllTests.testsuite" that is in the grandparent directory. Go to the Behavior tab, remove the invocation to the old test suite (ABC - invocation). Insert > Invocation > browse to the new test suite. Save the editor. 8. In the cases where there are other test suites that link to ABC.testsuite, those also have to be changed, using the same technique as in #7. 9. Delete the ABC.testsuite from CVS, add the BugzillaComponent.testsuite into CVS, and update the AllTests.testsuite in CVS.
-Moving test suites- 1. Create a brand new test suite. (Follow the instructions in README.txt.) http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/test-results/platform/org.eclipse.hyades.tests/README.txt?rev=HEAD&cvsroot=TPTP_Project&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup
2. Manually copy the test cases from the old test suite into the new test suite. 3. Follow #7, #8, and #9.
-Splitting test suites or merging test suites- If you need to split up tests amongst test suites, then create several new test suites and add the appropriate tests. Similarly for merging test suites, create a single new test suite and add the test cases from the old test suites into the new.
Assigned to Scott who is working on it.
Refactoring of test project test suites is complete. ACTION: Please verify/close this defect. Closing

Bug.Summery: Derby trigger DDL generation incorrect
Bug.WithStack: Derby uses the generic DDL generation for the triggers and the generated code is incorrect. A blank space needs to be added before the action clause. Apllied fix on July 20th, 2005. Verified fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack: Derby uses the generic DDL generation for the triggers and the generated code is incorrect. A blank space needs to be added before the action clause. Apllied fix on July 20th, 2005. Verified fixed.

Bug.Summery: Schema validation errors when disconnected from internet

Lines.Line: 1) The error description is just "java.sun.com" and doesn't tell the user what
the actual problem is. (can't connect to internet to validate against the schema)
2) Not being able to validate a DD should not be an error. In my case, the files
were correct (they were the initial ones generated from our project creation
wizards), so showing an error message was pretty user un-friendly. At most this
should have been a warning, and even then it's a little ugly. In my case, I
would prefer to have never seen this message at all - it should almost be a
Should be resolved with the new caching scheme
I don't mean to play "hot potato" but I think you missed part of the
significance of Tim's comments, Chuck. Mainly, if the schema is not available
(either because no net work, or because not yet cached (and, don't forget,
caching can be set off), then at most there should be a warning that "schema
could not be loaded" ... which, I believe is what the XML Validator does ... is
there other "validation" you are doing, or forcing that had a stronger requirement?

Bug.WithStack:
I'm not sure which component handles validation of web.xml and ejb-jar.xml files, so I'm opening the bug here. Please feel free to move it.
When I'm using RC1 and not connected to the internet, errors appear against the DD files. There are two problems:
1) The error description is just "java.sun.com" and doesn't tell the user what the actual problem is. (can't connect to internet to validate against the schema)
2) Not being able to validate a DD should not be an error. In my case, the files were correct (they were the initial ones generated from our project creation wizards), so showing an error message was pretty user un-friendly. At most this should have been a warning, and even then it's a little ugly. In my case, I would prefer to have never seen this message at all - it should almost be a preference. Should be resolved with the new caching scheme I don't mean to play "hot potato" but I think you missed part of the significance of Tim's comments, Chuck. Mainly, if the schema is not available (either because no net work, or because not yet cached (and, don't forget, caching can be set off), then at most there should be a warning that "schema could not be loaded" ... which, I believe is what the XML Validator does ... is there other "validation" you are doing, or forcing that had a stronger requirement?
If not, please return to me, and we'll investigate xml validator further. I suspect main xml validator bug here is the "java.sun.com" part, described in Bug 104454.
Chuck, do your web and ejb validators call the xml validator explcitly? Is there mulitiple validation going on in that case?
I'll pipe in now. The XML validator is probably the one producing these messages. Several problems with disconnected validation have been brought to light recently. These types of problems are difficult for the XML validator to diagnose at this point as the problem may be that the file cannot be located because there is no internet connection or because the file does not exist. Currently Xerces handles many of the network connections and the associated errors.
Tim, you suggested two possible solutions. 1) Show a warning message that says the file cannot be validated because a specific resource cannot be located. 2) Do not show any warning or error when the file can't be validated because a remote resource is unavailable.
I think a combination or 1 and 2 will work best. Show warning messages if there is no internet connection but have a preference to turn off the warning messages.
Comments?
I'll need to investigate to see how I can override the Xerces network resolution and determine that a network connection is not present.
I'm going to wait for Chuck to respond about the EJB and Web validators before taking ownership of this bug. Thanks Lawrence, I'll pipe in on the warning ... I think should always be a warning since 1) it might be invalid we do not know (just one per resource, though, not other warnings/errors on that file), and 2) users can turn off warnings already in preferences, so not worth adding prefernce clutter.
I agree with keeping preference clutter to a minimum. We can go with no preference unless a specific requirement emerges. Our validators don't invoke the XML validation (they run seperatly). And concentrate on aspects not covered by the basic schema validation.
I have also seen this, and a warning is appropriate - I agree with David, we should avoid the pref. *** Bug 104454 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Created attachment 25286 Patch that fixes the IOException error messages and addresses a possible infinite loop.
This patch incorporates a fix from Nitin's patch.
I've changed the following errors to warnings. Tim's reported problem is fixed by the first message.
Unable to connect to host: "{0}". -> The file cannot be validated as the host "{0}" is currently unreachable.
File not found: "{0}". -> The file cannot be validated as the XML Schema "{0}" that is specified as describing the syntax of the file cannot be located.
Connection problem: connect The file cannot be validated as there was a connection problem. I should add that the fix does not handle 2.4 deployment descriptors. These descriptors reference a J2EE schema. A warning is produced when the schema cannot be read but the files are declared invalid as a definition for the root element cannot be located. The error message in this case is more informative but should probably not be displayed if the schema cannot be located.
The fix for the 2.4 deployment descriptor is a higher risk as it will probably involve a larger change to the validator. At this point I think the fix for the messages Tim has pointed out as well as the fix for the possible infinite loop Nitin has provided a patch for should be addressed. I will continue to work on a solution for the 2.4 deployment descriptor. Nitin and Tim, if you're satisfied with the proposed fix as is I will request approval from the PMC for 0.7. Please take a look ASAP.
Thanks. Yup, I'm satisfied with the proposed patch. +1 Fix committed to RC4 build. Closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
I'm not sure which component handles validation of web.xml and ejb-jar.xml files, so I'm opening the bug here. Please feel free to move it.
When I'm using RC1 and not connected to the internet, errors appear against the DD files. There are two problems:
1) The error description is just "java.sun.com" and doesn't tell the user what the actual problem is. (can't connect to internet to validate against the schema)
2) Not being able to validate a DD should not be an error. In my case, the files were correct (they were the initial ones generated from our project creation wizards), so showing an error message was pretty user un-friendly. At most this should have been a warning, and even then it's a little ugly. In my case, I would prefer to have never seen this message at all - it should almost be a preference. Should be resolved with the new caching scheme I don't mean to play "hot potato" but I think you missed part of the significance of Tim's comments, Chuck. Mainly, if the schema is not available (either because no net work, or because not yet cached (and, don't forget, caching can be set off), then at most there should be a warning that "schema could not be loaded" ... which, I believe is what the XML Validator does ... is there other "validation" you are doing, or forcing that had a stronger requirement?
If not, please return to me, and we'll investigate xml validator further. I suspect main xml validator bug here is the "java.sun.com" part, described in Bug 104454.
Chuck, do your web and ejb validators call the xml validator explcitly? Is there mulitiple validation going on in that case?
I'll pipe in now. The XML validator is probably the one producing these messages. Several problems with disconnected validation have been brought to light recently. These types of problems are difficult for the XML validator to diagnose at this point as the problem may be that the file cannot be located because there is no internet connection or because the file does not exist. Currently Xerces handles many of the network connections and the associated errors.
Tim, you suggested two possible solutions. 1) Show a warning message that says the file cannot be validated because a specific resource cannot be located. 2) Do not show any warning or error when the file can't be validated because a remote resource is unavailable.
I think a combination or 1 and 2 will work best. Show warning messages if there is no internet connection but have a preference to turn off the warning messages.

Bug.Summery: NPE for content assist in EL region in text node
Bug.WithStack:
If an EL region appears in an "arbitrary" text node, and content assist requested there, a nasty error dialog pops up about a null pointer comes up.
Looking at the code, this was basically due to an assumption that a (dom) text node is always one structured document region.
This main fix, to avoid the NPE is pretty simple, which is to get the region directly from the document, instead of the DOM. I beleive this is a "contaner region" so that would have to be interated through to work correctly for EL regions in text nodes.
In fact, this still doesn't fix content assist there, since we are also checking to see if its an "attribtute value region". But, since I'm not sure what other work/assumptions are being made ... or will need to be made ... to get this to work correctly, I will just avoid the NPE for now, for RC2. The functional enhancement can some later. Ted, I've committed changes that fix the NPE to HEAD, but won't release for build until you review and confirm agreement.
Please see
JSPELContentAssistProcessor.java revision 1.3
(And, actually, I'm having trouble confirming CA still works with your latest EL parser changes ... I'll take a closer look later).
Thanks. Start with pageContext. I've turned off completion on the maps due to lack of interesting use cases.
Could you let me know what you changed? It looks like you did the reformat trick so I'm having a hard time picking out the change in the diff. changes to computeCompletionProposals(ITextViewer, int)
mostly to use
ContentAssistUtils.getStructuredDocumentRegion((StructuredTextViewer) viewer, documentPosition);
instead of IndexedRegion treeNode = ContentAssistUtils.getNodeAt((StructuredTextViewer) viewer, documentPosition);
IDOMNode xNode = null; IStructuredDocumentRegion flat = null; if (treeNode instanceof IDOMNode) { xNode = (IDOMNode) treeNode; flat = xNode.getFirstStructuredDocumentRegion();
BTW ... we do have a "team format" in repository ... SSE Format preferences, though I know we are inconsistent in its use. But there was not that many formatting 'diffs' (3 or 5).
I could get content assist to work if I put in whole word "pageContext" ... I thought there was more than that (such as complete 'pageContext' itself.
The change you've made looks fine. I'm still getting the hang of the right way to do document traversals.
As an aside, the java source compare showed 20 or so changes.
Right now we complete on pageContext members and taglib functions. We should be able to add contect variables without too much problem. I will open a bug for that.
Thanks,
Ted C. released for 7/20 I-build (approx. 0800).
This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP defects already verified by the reporter but awaiting closure by the assignee. If you feel this defect was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
Thanks, John Lanuti

Bug.Summery: Recurse is not a verb
Bug.WithStack: In the check in options 'Recurse into...' is an option. This is not a verb, it's recur. That may be so but it is often used in reference to this behavior of CVS. We want our tooling to be consistent with the terminology used by CVS.
Bug.WithOutStack: In the check in options 'Recurse into...' is an option. This is not a verb, it's recur. That may be so but it is often used in reference to this behavior of CVS. We want our tooling to be consistent with the terminology used by CVS.

Bug.Summery: Common tab missing on Ant Build for Java Project Properties Builders
Bug.WithStack:
When Bug 23064 and Bug 78799 were fixed, the Capture Output checkbox was removed. However, the Common tab is not visible from at least one more place, i.e., in the dialog for a Java project: Properties, Builders, an Ant Build.
(True, Common tab is there for Run, External Tools... from the main menu.)
To reproduce, create a Java project. Select Project, Properties, Builders. Click on New... button, select an Ant Build external tool. Give it a name. Click OK.
The Main tab no longer has Capture Output (fine). But, there is no Common tab after Build Options tab, which is the new place to control capturing the output. Adding the common tab for builders does not work well...Saving the launch configuration in a different locaiton and displaying in the favorites menu are not applicable.
I propose to add the Standard input and output group to the Build Options tab for builders. Copied the required code from the Common tab and applied the corrections needed for the ExternalToolBuilderTab. Changes to ExternalToolsLaunchConfigurationMessages nls class as well. Please verify Kevin. verified.

When Bug 23064 and Bug 78799 were fixed, the Capture Output checkbox was removed. However, the Common tab is not visible from at least one more place, i.e., in the dialog for a Java project: Properties, Builders, an Ant Build.

Bug.Summery: [discussion] prototype extension of java support to work with AspectJ/AJDT
Bug.WithStack:
This involves extending the structure bridges and UI like the cross-references view. Created attachment 25014 first patch Hey Jeff,
I made the code adhere to our conventions, cleaned it up, and committed it. Also, note that I put up instructions for a convenient way to work with AJDT installed: http://eclipse.org/mylar/dev.html
I had to remove most of the extension points in plugin.xml because these should not duplicate the ones in mylar.java. Those extensions will run with AspectJ around since the mylar.java plug-in will be loaded.
Let me know if you have any questions about what's been done so far. Also, note that the plug-in is not starting up right now. I know how to fix that, but first wanted to check why you had two different plug-in classes. In light of the fact that the core org.eclipse.mylar.java stuff moslty works for AJDT (e.g. Package Explorer and Outline filtering) I think that the first thing to do to make progress on this task is for us to Outline the things that don't work. Ideally that would be done in conjunction with a user interested in using Mylar with AJDT, so I'll see if I can solicit someone. I would like this report to be a discussion of what it means for Mylar to support AJDT well, and then have specific tasks become seperate reports. Thanks to AJDT's increasing compatability with the JDT's Java Model the Mylar Java stuff already goes part of the way to supporting AJDT. What we need now is someone interested in using both to outline and prioritize the key things that don't work well (e.g. wanting the mylar glasses for the xref view).
Matt, Ron, and Ramnivas, I have added you to this report in case you are interested in trying the Mylar UI and commenting. There's a 5 minute tutorial video at: http://eclipse.org/mylar/doc/demo/mylar-demo-03.html If you have not made it to Phase 1 of the user study email mylar@cs.ubc.ca to get the update site. Any bad interactions between Mylar and AJDT should now be made seperate bug reports.

Bug.Summery: Don't issue missing doc warning for hidden members
Bug.WithStack:
If javadoc warnings for the scope protected and above are enabled, there should be no missing comment warnings for any members of a member with a visibility less than protected.
E.g.
public class A { private class Bla extends AbstractAction { public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) { ... } } }
There should be no "missing javadoc" warning, since the whole class will never get into the javadoc because of private visibility... So pretty sensless to issue a warning and especially if one uses a lot of inner/anonymous classes this is more than annoying. And because of the bunch of warnings I've seen a lot of people starting to ignore/filter out or even disable those warnings. And thus finally makes the complete warning system superfluous or at least to degrade its usage to not production ready ... Moving to JDT/Core.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 86769 *** It might be a duplicate, but 86769 has been marked as resolved, which isn't true ... It's *really* a duplicate. Bug 86769 was marked as RESOLVED but status was LATER. That means bugs is NOT resolved but will be fixed later... This is the way bugzilla works. If you think this behavior is not good, please open a requirement against it...
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 86769 ***

Bug.Summery: Bad validation error on page 3 of the Web service client wizard

Lines.Line: 1. Configure a Tomcat 5.0 and a 4.0 server in the Preferences ... Servers >
2. Create a Web project targetted to Tomcat 5.0 (wp5).
3. Launch the Web service client wizard
Page 3: Select "Edit" and choose the tomcat 4.0 server. A validation error
will appear saying that "wp5 has a server target which is not compatible ...".
4. Enter a new project name (wp4). The validation error should go away, but it
does not, preventing the user from going forward.

Bug.WithStack:
Using WTP 0.7 RC1:
1. Configure a Tomcat 5.0 and a 4.0 server in the Preferences ... Servers > Installed runtimes 2. Create a Web project targetted to Tomcat 5.0 (wp5). 3. Launch the Web service client wizard Page 1: Next. Page 2: Enter http://www.xmethods.net/sd/2001/TemperatureService.wsdl Page 3: Select "Edit" and choose the tomcat 4.0 server. A validation error will appear saying that "wp5 has a server target which is not compatible ...". 4. Enter a new project name (wp4). The validation error should go away, but it does not, preventing the user from going forward. Created attachment 25017 apply to org.eclipse.jst.ws.consumption.ui
patch 1 of 1 The attached patch is ready to be committed. I realize it's likely too late to get this into 0.7 but since the fix is so simple and low risk, I decided to attach the patch anyway. The problem is that ClientRuntimeSelectionWidget is not calling the right getter on ProjectSelectionWidget to get the project name and ear project name for validation purposes. Instead, it's calling a getter that really should be removed entirely from the class since it does not return the currently selected value of these fields but rather what they were when the page initially came up. I'd like for this to be in 0.7 because it's a pretty fundamental problem with page 3 validation (client wizard only), could be very annoying and limiting to users, and the fix is extremely low risk. I've reviewed the fix and, its simplicity weighed against the prospect of blocking users who have more than one type of server, something that would not seem uncommon, agree we should pull this into RC2. Committed and released, v20050719_1900. Verified Closing

Bug.Summery: Register view can not show correct value when switch between different thread or stack frame
Bug.WithStack:
Debug a program having 2 threads with register view open, the program stops after breakpoint hit, then select another thread or stack frame, the register value remain unchanged. Is this on a single core or a multi core system? Which debugger are you using? If you run you debugger outside of the CDT does you get the results you expected? Selection of a stack frame or thread doesn't force the reevaluation of register values. Fix in the head.
Mikhail, could you verify this, if your tests are satisfactory we can consider, this last issue fixed(and finally release CDT-3.0)
Thanks. Fixed. Verfied. There is still a minor defect :
Each time the stackframe is switched, CDT has to query GDB again for the register list, which is very slow if GDB has a very long register list. In some cases, the register value is not changed at all, and it is not necessay for CDT to query GDB.
For example, when a breakpoint hits, the user switches back and forth between different stackframe to inspect the register value, in this case, to re-query the register state is not necessary.
Can somehow CDT implement a cache mechanism, so that in such cases, CDT does not re-query GDB for register value? The performance issue is I think a separate issue. I think it belongs in its own PR; the issue that was filed has been fixed. Determining update policies for the debug views is currently being debated in the DSDP Project's Device Debugging sub-project. I think it's appropriate to approach this separately as a post-3.0 task, aligned with DSDP. Moving to future to keep of 3.0 gating list. Mikhail, please review and adjust as you see fit. I agree with Chris. I've submitted a new bug for the performance issue (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=106398).

Bug.Summery: Support migration of one module project to multiple
Bug.WithStack:
Using WTP SDK 0.7RC1
Create a new dynamic project with "Allow Multiple modules per project" turned OFF. Call the project "P1" This should create a project with a module in the root of the project
Now turn "Allow Multiple modules per project" turned ON Create a new module and add it to the project created in the previous step. Call the module "Mod1"
(Bug 1) I had to close and re-open the workbench to see an entry in the project navigator for both deployment descriptors.
Open the web editor (Web.xml) on the deployment descriptor for P1. Add a new security role called "P1Admin". Save and close the editor
(Bug2) Expand the deployment descriptor info in the navigator for both modules and you will see that the security role does not show in either. It should show under "P1"
Open the web editor on the deployment descriptor for "Mod1" Add a new security role called "Mod1Admin". Save and close the editor
(Bug3) Expand the deployment descriptor info in the navigator for both modules and you will see that the security role does not show in either. It should show under "P1"
close and re-open the workbench
(Bug4) Expand the deployment descriptor info in the navigator for both modules and you will see that both P1 and Mod1 show the "Mod1Admin role The main problem here is we don't support yet moving a one module project defined with preference off to a multiple with preference on. We would need to add this support and then the rest of the scenarios would work.
The refresh issue is a duplicate of 103383.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 103383 *** Verified closing

Bug.Summery: Remove potentially disruptive line of code in bugzilla connection php sample
Bug.WithStack:
The commented lines of code:
# For debugging purposes - don't display this stuff in a production page. # echo mysql_error($dbh);
if uncommented, will cause a previously working script to dump an empty HTML document instead (<html><body></body></html>). After a painful bit of debugging and testing to discover this, I thought it might be helpful to others to warn them of this "but it worked a second ago!" pain.
Removing the two lines will prevent users from running into this headache, in the event - like me - that they want to see the SQL error message thrown from (potentially) bad SQL.
Cheers,
Nick I fixed the sample code. The line causing the error was this one:
echo "There was an error processing this request".
The "." at the end assumed a concatination, hence uncommenting the following echo command caused a boo boo.
D.

if uncommented, will cause a previously working script to dump an empty HTML document instead (<html><body></body></html>). After a painful bit of debugging and testing to discover this, I thought it might be helpful to others to warn them of this "but it worked a second ago!" pain.

D.

Bug.Summery: Clear Task Context Fails for a bugzilla task in a query
Bug.WithStack: The clear context action fails for a BugzillaTask in a query since it is really a BugzillaHit that is wrapping a BugzillaTask. So should we try to make this work? Are you doing anything in your own workspace to work-around this limitation, or just not clearing contexts? Admitedly I almost never do it myself unless I'm testing... The only workaround that exists is to create a bugzilla task with the same bug id outside of the query so that it is a regular task. I do use this on occasion, especially when exploring and the context becomes overrun with information that is not useful to the task and I want to start fresh. OK, let's leave it as a limitation for now, since there is a clear work-around and it's not clear how much this feature will get used.

OK, let's leave it as a limitation for now, since there is a clear work-around and it's not clear how much this feature will get used.

Bug.Summery: [Navigator] Navigator can become non-functional when using subsets
Bug.WithStack:
When using a subset view in Navigator (for example, by performing a 'go into' command into a displayed folder), Navigator can become non-functional under the following condition: - The project in which the folder was last time displayed no longer exists.
When this happens, Navigator shows an empty panel, with the name of the subset in which it was at the last Eclipse exiting; at this point there is no way to get out of that non-existent subset; Navigator displays the message: "you attempted to go into a closed project: ProjectName. Please open the project and try again." (The message is displayed two times and then there is no progress.)
As the project ProjectName no longer exists, there is no easy way out of this 'deadlock' situation. The one work around I found was to re-create a similar project, with a similar folder structure, go back to Navigator, then succesfully press the up arrow until the subset mode is fully exited, and then finally restart Eclipse and delete the dummy project.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When using a subset view in Navigator (for example, by performing a 'go into' command into a displayed folder), Navigator can become non-functional under the following condition: - The project in which the folder was last time displayed no longer exists.
When this happens, Navigator shows an empty panel, with the name of the subset in which it was at the last Eclipse exiting; at this point there is no way to get out of that non-existent subset; Navigator displays the message: "you attempted to go into a closed project: ProjectName. Please open the project and try again." (The message is displayed two times and then there is no progress.)
As the project ProjectName no longer exists, there is no easy way out of this 'deadlock' situation. The one work around I found was to re-create a similar project, with a similar folder structure, go back to Navigator, then succesfully press the up arrow until the subset mode is fully exited, and then finally restart Eclipse and delete the dummy project.

Bug.Summery: WS-I SOAP validator does not function
Bug.WithStack:
Working in RC1, I logged some non-SOAP messages in the TCP/IP monitor. I then selected a message and chose to validate it. The WS-I SOAP validate dialog appeared. I chose a location, clicked finish, and nothing happened.
I haven't yet tested this with a SOAP message but hopefully this problem only occurs with non-SOAP messages. With non-SOAP messages the WS-I SOAP validate button should be disabled (this will probably require a new hook in the TCP/IP monitor that allows you to get the content type) but at least the dialog should inform you that you cannot validate non-SOAP messages. Created attachment 43608 patch to org.eclipse.wst.wsi
Non-SOAP messages typically have an empty body. This was causing the validator to throw a NPE while generating the log.wsimsg file The NPE was going undetected and causing the termination of the validation process. So actually, if your monitor were to capture a mixture of SOAP and non-SOAP messages, you would get the same lack of a result.
I have attached a patch that detects request or response messages with empty headers or bodies and omits them from the generated log file. If this causes no messages to get logged, the validator will pop up an error dialog informing the user of this and stop the validation process at that point. Created attachment 43609 patch to org.eclipse.wst.wsi.ui
Related patch for the ui plugin Created attachment 43610 JUnit tests for 104428
This zip file contains a new project (since no test project currently exists for org.eclipse.wst.wsi.ui). The test class in this project shows how an empty header or body on a request or response will cause a NPE. ping? Status update? There's a patch and junit test for this. Any possibility of getting it addressed?
Bug.WithOutStack:
Working in RC1, I logged some non-SOAP messages in the TCP/IP monitor. I then selected a message and chose to validate it. The WS-I SOAP validate dialog appeared. I chose a location, clicked finish, and nothing happened.

Bug.Summery: AC doesn't check agent availability
Bug.WithStack: The Agent Controller is supposed to check an agent's metadata to determine whether or not it allows multiple controllers and/or multiple observers. However, it is currently allowing access to everyone who requests it as long as the agent itself is found. Added implementation for agentManager_checkAccess As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. Bug.Summery: Should include jdt-apt source code with jdt feature
Bug.WithStack: We should include our source code with the modified jdt. BTW, make sure the dir names under the source plugin structure have version numbers that match what is specified in the corresponding plugin manifests. Otherwise the PDE dev environment won't be able to make the connection between the JDT plugins and their source... Fixed in the manifests and in the exportplugin scripts.
Bug.WithOutStack: We should include our source code with the modified jdt. BTW, make sure the dir names under the source plugin structure have version numbers that match what is specified in the corresponding plugin manifests. Otherwise the PDE dev environment won't be able to make the connection between the JDT plugins and their source... Fixed in the manifests and in the exportplugin scripts.

Bug.Summery: [content assist] Should do completion on implicit objects in EL.
Bug.WithStack:
The available implicit objects are:
pageContext: The context for the JSP page. Provides access to various objects param: Maps a request parameter name to a single value paramValues: Maps a request parameter name to an array of values header: Maps a request header name to a single value headerValues: Maps a request header name to an array of values cookie: Maps a cookie name to a single cookie initParam: Maps a context initialization parameter name to a single value pageScope: Maps page-scoped variable names to their values requestScope: Maps request-scoped variable names to their values sessionScope: Maps session-scoped variable names to their values applicationScope: Maps application-scoped variable names to their values Walter, interested in fixing this bug?
This should be relatively easy as javaEE's api's are stable. What's the status on this one? The status is that this is still an interesting idea, but we don't have people to work on this just now. We would accept high quality patches, though. Bug 280115 fixes content assist for pageContext - Limitation, right now this only appears to work when the EL is in tag attributes, further work is needed to eliminate this limitation.
As far as code assist for the maps, what would be given in the code assist dialog. As far as I understand it the keys for the map are determined at run time and thus we have no way of determining what keys to code assist with during development. Please correct me if I am mistaken. Bug 281508 fixes content assist for EL that is not in attributes. Again this content assist for the implicit objects only works on pageContext because the others are maps and as far as I can tell from what I was reading about EL there is no way to know what will be in these maps before run time so content assist cant suggest anything for them. If I am wrong in this regard please let me know what you would expect to see for content assist for the maps. I am thinking that when invoking content assist in this context ${ | } the implicit objects themselves should be suggested.

The available implicit objects are:

Bug.Summery: AC doesn't filter requests by interface
Bug.WithStack: Several of the Agent Controller commands are supposed to provide and option of filtering requests by interface. However, the Agent Controller currently ignores the interfaces parameter. This is required for full API support This relies on Java or C++ clients implementing the interface to pass in interfaces to use as filters, but the Agent Controller portion is implemented. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: AC doesn't send error responses
Bug.WithStack: If an error occurs during the processing of a command sent to the Agent Controller, the command fails silently. No response is sent. Currently, if an error occurs the component that sent the command receives no notification whatsoever. This is generally unacceptable. The Agent Manager now uses the TPTP_Error command with the context ID of the command in which the error occurred. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: Clients aren't notified if their agents deregister
Bug.WithStack:
If an agent that is in use deregisters or otherwise disappears, the client is not notified. Clients are notified with one of the following commands:
<agentDeregistered iid="org.eclipse.tptp.AgentManager"><agentID>###</agentID></agentDeregistered>
or
<agentProcessExited iid="org.eclipse.tptp.AgentManager"><agentID>###</agentID></agentProcessExited>
Which command will be sent depends upon whether or not the agent sends a deregistration notification to the agent controller (and whether or not the AC receives said notification before it receives notification that the agent's process exited). As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.
Bug.WithOutStack:
If an agent that is in use deregisters or otherwise disappears, the client is not notified. Clients are notified with one of the following commands:
<agentDeregistered iid="org.eclipse.tptp.AgentManager"><agentID>###</agentID></agentDeregistered>
or
<agentProcessExited iid="org.eclipse.tptp.AgentManager"><agentID>###</agentID></agentProcessExited>
Which command will be sent depends upon whether or not the agent sends a deregistration notification to the agent controller (and whether or not the AC receives said notification before it receives notification that the agent's process exited). As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Bug.Summery: [build path] Native libraries should be able to be added to source folders too.
Bug.WithStack:
Currently if you have a jar in your classpath, you can, using the build path ui, add in native library paths. You should be able to do this for your source code too so that when launching the project any native required by the code being developed should be able to access its own dlls.
I tried, for the heck of it, to manually update the .classpath file and add the appropriate elements for a library to the src classpath entry and it launched fine and added that to the library path. So it looks like the base code for using it is already there.
Thanks.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 97429 ***

Bug.Summery: Logging service needs to be integrated

Lines.Line: 1. Integrate the AC logging service code
2. Implement configuration handling to set the AC logging level
3. Map TPTP_LOG_XXXXXX macros to code that will send messages to the AC
4. (?) Implement per agent logging level configurability
5. Determine how shared DLLs can best get their logging messages directed to
7. (?) Implement a way to set logging level at run-time

Bug.WithStack:
We currently have macros in place to handle logging of debug and error messages, but the messages are not channeled to log files or converted into CBE format. The bulk of the code to do this is available but hasn't been integrated.
The following things need to be done:
1. Integrate the AC logging service code 2. Implement configuration handling to set the AC logging level 3. Map TPTP_LOG_XXXXXX macros to code that will send messages to the AC logging service 4. (?) Implement per agent logging level configurability 5. Determine how shared DLLs can best get their logging messages directed to the log 6. Implement shared library logging 7. (?) Implement a way to set logging level at run-time Andy,
This seems related to the AC tracing feature (bug # 79564). Does it make sense to combine it?
-Sri

Bug.Summery: (Linux) Agent Controller doesn't perform correct startup
Bug.WithStack:
The Agent Controller does not currently perform the necessary tasks on start up. It does not register signal handlers, and it does not have a way of waiting for server threads to complete.
The previous version waited for server threads at the end of its initialization, but now that those threads have been moved to transport layers it is unclear how the equivalent function can be accomplished. Kevin,
I know you did some work with this. Is it finished? I uncommented the section of AgentController.c that dealt with linux signal handlers. needed to back out this fix... we need to understand how this is effecting console. Is this still an issue?
Yes... this issue is specific to linux. We do not create signal handlers on AC startup. Retarget to 4.3.
We don't have a specific user-level bug associated with this and it's too risky at this point in the release to mess with the signal handlers. Retargeting to future as 4.3 is closing down to all non-essential bug fixing. Transferring ownership of new agemt controller issues with no specific target date to Mikhail for consideration in future releases. Assign to Stanislav As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution.
