Bug.Summery: Need to guard against caching of the environment, messager and filer
Bug.WithStack:
Currently we fail with an NPE. Should instead throw an IllegalStateException if something is cached beyond its lifetime.
See especially ProcessorEnvImpl.addProblem(). Added checkValid() calls from the Messager, Environment and Filer as needed.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Currently we fail with an NPE. Should instead throw an IllegalStateException if something is cached beyond its lifetime.
See especially ProcessorEnvImpl.addProblem(). Added checkValid() calls from the Messager, Environment and Filer as needed.

Bug.Summery: Improve GUI for processor options
Bug.WithStack: At present processor options are specified with a single text field. It should be (ideally) a PropertyGrid or (at least) a table of keys and values. Is now a table. Leaving this bug open, but changing sev to "enhancement", because I want to put in some sort of clipboard functionality so that people can copy/paste command lines. Not for 3.2. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack: At present processor options are specified with a single text field. It should be (ideally) a PropertyGrid or (at least) a table of keys and values. Is now a table. Leaving this bug open, but changing sev to "enhancement", because I want to put in some sort of clipboard functionality so that people can copy/paste command lines. Not for 3.2. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: [build path] "compiler settings changed" dialog appears multiple times
Bug.WithStack:
If compiler settings are changed on more than one preference pane (e.g., on "Java Compiler", "Building", and "Errors/Warnings"), and the user clicks OK, the Compiler Settings Changed dialog will then appear once for each modified preference pane.
This is the dialog that asks "A rebuild of the project is required for changes to take effect. Build the project now?". It is not clear what the effect is, if the user answers "no" to the question on one of the dialogs and "yes" on another. It is also not clear whether multiple build jobs are actually being submitted.
I expected to only see the pane appear once per click of OK, rather than once per modified pane. *** Bug 103587 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 104938 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The problem is that preference pages don't know each other. So they can not coordinate who is going to ask for the rebuild.
I implemented a kind of hack to use a preference setting in the default settings to signal that a build has been requested. Works for all subclasses of OptionsConfigurationBlock
fixed > 20051201 Verified in I20051213-0010.
Bug.WithOutStack:
If compiler settings are changed on more than one preference pane (e.g., on "Java Compiler", "Building", and "Errors/Warnings"), and the user clicks OK, the Compiler Settings Changed dialog will then appear once for each modified preference pane.
This is the dialog that asks "A rebuild of the project is required for changes to take effect. Build the project now?". It is not clear what the effect is, if the user answers "no" to the question on one of the dialogs and "yes" on another. It is also not clear whether multiple build jobs are actually being submitted.
I expected to only see the pane appear once per click of OK, rather than once per modified pane. *** Bug 103587 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 104938 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The problem is that preference pages don't know each other. So they can not coordinate who is going to ask for the rebuild.
I implemented a kind of hack to use a preference setting in the default settings to signal that a build has been requested. Works for all subclasses of OptionsConfigurationBlock
fixed > 20051201 Verified in I20051213-0010.

Bug.Summery: single-line comments are scanned incorrectly if file contains Mac OS line endings (stand-alone CRs)
Bug.WithStack:
Bugzilla got anxious and posted without my description. Here it is:
If you open a file containing single carriage return characters (\r as opposed to paired \r\n) the comment highlighting is wrong. Basically it colors your entire file as commented from the first // comment onwards. Very bad and misleading. Note that the Eclipse platform itself does handle these files correctly - default line endings are { "\r", "\n", "\r\n" }. The problem appears to be in FastCPartitionScanner. Created attachment 25020 file with linefeeds (works) Created attachment 25021 file with carriage returns (does not work) Created attachment 25022 file with both LF/CR (works) Created attachment 25025 support for legal line delimiters
This will detect all the legal line delimiters correctly. Created attachment 25100 revised patch
Revised patch. Passes JUnit conformance tests. fixed in head ???
Bug.WithOutStack:
Bugzilla got anxious and posted without my description. Here it is:
If you open a file containing single carriage return characters (\r as opposed to paired \r\n) the comment highlighting is wrong. Basically it colors your entire file as commented from the first // comment onwards. Very bad and misleading. Note that the Eclipse platform itself does handle these files correctly - default line endings are { "\r", "\n", "\r\n" }. The problem appears to be in FastCPartitionScanner. Created attachment 25020 file with linefeeds (works) Created attachment 25021 file with carriage returns (does not work) Created attachment 25022 file with both LF/CR (works) Created attachment 25025 support for legal line delimiters
This will detect all the legal line delimiters correctly. Created attachment 25100 revised patch
Revised patch. Passes JUnit conformance tests. fixed in head ???

Bug.Summery: Disabled GUI elements need tooltips giving "enable help"

Lines.Line: - what the user has to do to enable it.
* Widgets can be excepted from this policy if the position and context of the
widget make this obvious; such as indented under another, deselected widget.
* Widgets definitely have to have such a tooltip where the controlling
parameters can not be set from the same widget group or even dialog page.

Janet, this request is to have a tooltip explaining why a disabled element in the GUI is in fact disabled. Is there a consistent way that the platform handles this type of information? Is the consistent way not to have the information available?
I don't think there has ever been a requirement/bug to have tooltips on disabled icons to explain why they are disabled. So there wouldn't be a consistent way to display the information.

Bug.WithStack:
Every GUI item which is disabled should have a tooltip explaining why it is disabled and what the user has to do in order to enable it. This does not only apply to the WTP but is especially important there due to the many and widely dispersed parameters which determine the state of a GUI element.
Eg when doing the first tutorial I get to the point where it says: " 3. [...] Type the Servlet Name, "XDcoletHelloWorld". Make sure "Generate an annotated servlet class" is checked. "
The box is disabled. I have no idea why. I double checked all settings and still have no clue. A simple tooltip saying "no available for XXX" would be extremely helpful here. This is just one of several examples I have come across while trying the tutorials. As there are potentially many places where options are disabled can you please specify the ones you've come across (that have confused you) so I have a list to start with.
After I get a list I'll speak with the component owners to see what can be done.
Thanks. Unfortunately I didn't write them down until I decided to write the bug report. It would be better anyway to have a general policy here than to go by what is particularly confusing to me. This is probably different for other users with different backgrounds and level of experience. I would propose the following guidelines regarding this problem:
* Every widget when disabled should display a tooltip stating: - why it is disabled. - what the user has to do to enable it. * Widgets can be excepted from this policy if the position and context of the widget make this obvious; such as indented under another, deselected widget. * Widgets definitely have to have such a tooltip where the controlling parameters can not be set from the same widget group or even dialog page. Janet, this request is to have a tooltip explaining why a disabled element in the GUI is in fact disabled. Is there a consistent way that the platform handles this type of information? Is the consistent way not to have the information available? I don't think there has ever been a requirement/bug to have tooltips on disabled icons to explain why they are disabled. So there wouldn't be a consistent way to display the information.
However, it's ideal to use the dynamic help that was implemented in Eclipse 3.2M5 to store this type of information. I'm going to close this bug as won't fix. A lot of infopop (F1) documentaion has been added since this bug was opened.
Please open new bugs for specific cases where you find documentation lacking.
I still think that any disabled GUI element should have a tooltip explaining its state (and how to change it), but this is probably not the right place for this discussion. Feel free to bring up the conversation on the wtp-dev@eclipse.org list or on one of our weekly open status calls [1].
Closing bug.
[1]http://www.eclipse.org/webtools/development/status-telecons/index.html

Bug.Summery: Derby trigger template fails to deploy
Bug.WithStack: Deploying the Derby trigger template results in a NullPointer Exception inside the database engine. This is a Derby bug (http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DERBY-85) but we should either implement a workaround, or remove the trigger template. This is a Derby defect. It was communicated to Derby development to address this defect. Information provided.
Bug.WithOutStack: Deploying the Derby trigger template results in a NullPointer Exception inside the database engine. This is a Derby bug (http://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/DERBY-85) but we should either implement a workaround, or remove the trigger template. This is a Derby defect. It was communicated to Derby development to address this defect. Information provided.

Bug.Summery: Build is not automatically triggered for new dynamic web project on RoS
Bug.WithStack:
Scenario:
-Create a new Dynamic Web Project (not a flex project) -Add some simple content -Assign the project to the WLS 9.0 generic server runtime -With autobuild turned off and without explicitly executing a build on the project, execute RoS for an html file under WebContent
Result: the generic server Ant publish task fails because the .deployables dir has not been created.
Expected: Although I have auto-build turned off, I do have the "Build (if required) before launching" pref enabled, so I would expect this project to be automatically built before the publish attempt is made. note: using the 7/19 I-build Dropping severity and reassigning; I had been expecting that the "build (if required) before launching" would also apply to server launch config delegates (i.e. LaunchConfiguration.launch() would be calling ILaunchConfigurationDelegate2.buildForLaunch()), however, that doesn't appear to be happening due to the fact that Server is calling the ILaunchConfiguration.launch(String, IProgressMonitor) with the result that the build flag defaults to true; Tim: should the server framework be respecting the build before launch pref?). The issue of whether the server framework should also be handling builds automatically on module launch is a completely separate item (this would be a nice service to provide and could either be exposed via another server pref like "build (if required) before running modules" or the value of the existing build before launching pref could be assumed to hold for both cases). Hi Rob,
I agree that we should be honoring the 'build before launch' preference, and I'd lean towards reusing the existing run/debug preference instead of creating another preference. The reason we're calling the launch(String, IProgressMonitor) instead of the other method is simply that this code was written pre-3.0 when the other methods didn't exist.
Although I agree we need to do this, is it really critical for 0.7? The build preference is on by default and we've had this behaviour the entire time. It's not too unreasonable to tell users that they have to build before RoS. I think we can move this one to P4 and fix in M8. hey Tim: I agree that this can be pushed out. Will target to fix in M8. I've fixed the problem by triggering a build on every server start, although this probably is no longer necessary due to the removal of the .deployables directory. I did not add a preference for this yet (it is always on) and we'll see the reaction to this in the builds before deciding if this is necessary or if another preference should be added.
Changes dropped to HEAD, and I'll tag for this week's I-build. Were we not able to use the 'build before launch' preference? The debug 'Build before launch' preference is only in the UI layer and does not work if people call the debug API directly. In this case we're in a core (non-UI) plugin, so it doesn't make sense to try to reuse that preference. Just tested this with RC4 and, for a generic WLS 9.0 server, the project was not built on server start or ROS (I had auto-build turned off): obviously, the underlying server code has changed substantially since this fix was first put in and the removal of .deployables removes much of the motivation behind the original issue.
Tim: should I still be expecting to see a build triggered on server startup? Closing.

Scenario:
-Create a new Dynamic Web Project (not a flex project) -Add some simple content -Assign the project to the WLS 9.0 generic server runtime -With autobuild turned off and without explicitly executing a build on the project, execute RoS for an html file under WebContent
Result: the generic server Ant publish task fails because the .deployables dir has not been created.
Expected: Although I have auto-build turned off, I do have the "Build (if required) before launching" pref enabled, so I would expect this project to be automatically built before the publish attempt is made. note: using the 7/19 I-build Dropping severity and reassigning; I had been expecting that the "build (if required) before launching" would also apply to server launch config delegates (i.e. LaunchConfiguration.launch() would be calling ILaunchConfigurationDelegate2.buildForLaunch()), however, that doesn't appear to be happening due to the fact that Server is calling the ILaunchConfiguration.launch(String, IProgressMonitor) with the result that the build flag defaults to true; Tim: should the server framework be respecting the build before launch pref?). The issue of whether the server framework should also be handling builds automatically on module launch is a completely separate item (this would be a nice service to provide and could either be exposed via another server pref like "build (if required) before running modules" or the value of the existing build before launching pref could be assumed to hold for both cases). Hi Rob,
I agree that we should be honoring the 'build before launch' preference, and I'd lean towards reusing the existing run/debug preference instead of creating another preference. The reason we're calling the launch(String, IProgressMonitor) instead of the other method is simply that this code was written pre-3.0 when the other methods didn't exist.
Although I agree we need to do this, is it really critical for 0.7? The build preference is on by default and we've had this behaviour the entire time. It's not too unreasonable to tell users that they have to build before RoS. I think we can move this one to P4 and fix in M8. hey Tim: I agree that this can be pushed out. Will target to fix in M8. I've fixed the problem by triggering a build on every server start, although this probably is no longer necessary due to the removal of the .deployables directory. I did not add a preference for this yet (it is always on) and we'll see the reaction to this in the builds before deciding if this is necessary or if another preference should be added.
Changes dropped to HEAD, and I'll tag for this week's I-build. Were we not able to use the 'build before launch' preference? The debug 'Build before launch' preference is only in the UI layer and does not work if people call the debug API directly. In this case we're in a core (non-UI) plugin, so it doesn't make sense to try to reuse that preference. Just tested this with RC4 and, for a generic WLS 9.0 server, the project was not built on server start or ROS (I had auto-build turned off): obviously, the underlying server code has changed substantially since this fix was first put in and the removal of .deployables removes much of the motivation behind the original issue.
Tim: should I still be expecting to see a build triggered on server startup? Closing.

Bug.Summery: Issue when using a inherited Table component
Bug.WithStack:
VE is not handling correctly components that inherit from the standard SWT one.
To reproduce the issue: 1/ Create a new MyTable component, extending the Table one (override checkSubclss() method) 2/ Create a new MyTableColumn component, inheriting from TableColumn 3/ Drag & drop MyTable into a composite 4/ Drag & drop MyTableColumn on the table
=> The code is not generated correctly, as it assumes that SWT controls cannot be derived.
Joe Winchester is aware of this issue but I don't have his ID to assign the bug to him :-) Joe, are we really going to handle this? This is officially unsupported by the SWT folks so I'm not sure we should support it either...
What is the use case for this? Dave - I agree that this isn't officially support and to subclass anything other than Composite or Canvas requires the user to override the checkSubclass () method and is basically a hack. What we need to do is focus on having a good framework for a controller/wrapper/delegate such as JFace and publishing the tutorial/docs on this and then folks who want to effectively add behavior to an SWT widget can do so with strategy containment (which JFace viewers are an example of). Once 3.1 is cooked (which is today and I was up till 3am fixing last minute bugs) doing JFace is probably the highest line item and I hope to work on it next week. I will take a look at what it takes to allow TableColumn subclasses to be allowed because it might be a very simple fix in which case I'll report back what the change would be and what its impact is and then we can decide whether to check in a patch or not - JRW

What we need to do is focus on having a good framework for a controller/wrapper/delegate such as JFace and publishing the tutorial/docs on this and then folks who want to effectively add behavior to an SWT widget can do so with strategy containment (which JFace viewers are an example of). Bug.Summery: Publish is always executed on RoS regardless of whether project has been modified
Bug.WithStack:
I don't think I was seeing this prior to switching "startBeforePublish" to true for the WLS generic servers but now whenever I execute an RoS (testing this in a dynamic web project) a publish is performed despite the fact that nothing has been changed in the project (my recollection before was that these only seemed to be triggered when modifications had been made since the last publish).
Could setting startBeforePublish to true cause this behavior?
fyi: I'm using the 7/19 I-build (plus the most recent from HEAD for the various generic server plugins) Hi Rob,
This didn't change as a result of switching to startBeforePublish. It has always done a publish before Run on Server, just to make sure that things are in sync.
Publish is meant to be like building the workspace. When in doubt, a 'client' should always publish. The server adapters should have enough information (it has information on whether the module is new/changed/not changed/removed, and for each module it can also get the list of resources or the delta since the last publish) and be smart enough to not (or incrementally) publish when possible.
I think the 'when in doubt, publish' paradigm is correct, and although we could make the publish on Run on Server optional like the 'publish when starting' option, that's not really the problem here since it should be incremental even when the user clicks Publish in the Servers view. I'm guessing that either a particular server (or maybe the generic framework) is always triggering a full publish, even if nothing has changed.
Given the above, I'm going to return this bug as invalid. Please feel free to reopen if you have issues with my comments, and otherwise open a new bug or reopen this one against a particular server that is not supporting incremental publishing, or is publishing when there are no changes. hey Tim, thanks again for the detailed explanation; I must have only started noticing once the publish got pushed after the startup; yeah, the issue I'm having is with the a generic server that's using the AntPublisher - I'll talk to Gorkem and see if it makes more sense to try and add something into the generic server framework level or just augment the Ant publish script to do minimal work if things haven't changed. Closing.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I don't think I was seeing this prior to switching "startBeforePublish" to true for the WLS generic servers but now whenever I execute an RoS (testing this in a dynamic web project) a publish is performed despite the fact that nothing has been changed in the project (my recollection before was that these only seemed to be triggered when modifications had been made since the last publish).
Could setting startBeforePublish to true cause this behavior?

Bug.Summery: WebResource.getPath() is incorrect for a JSP unless the web folder is set to WebContent
Bug.WithStack:
This bug is file against RC1.
WebResource.getPath() works for a Web Project, if the source folder is WebContent, which is used the standard WTP Web App project wizard.
For custom file layout, the method return an incorrect path. An extra "\<Folder Name> is appended.
For example, the source folder is "web", and the jsp is "foo.jsp". The path returned is "\web\foo.jsp", instead of just "foo.jsp".
The problem doesn't occur with Servlet. Fix released 7.20 should make it to this evenings build. Verified fixed in RC5.
1/ Create a Web Project using default setting. 2/ Rename WebContent to Web 3/ update .wtpmodules 4/ Create a new jsp under Web and Run on Server Closing.

The problem doesn't occur with Servlet. Fix released 7.20 should make it to this evenings build. Verified fixed in RC5.

Bug.Summery: If plot background is set, data set binding is lost.

Lines.Line: 2.Set data: dataset, X Series, Y Series...
3.Set the image to the plot background

Bug.WithStack:
Steps: 1.Drag a chart into the layout 2.Set data: dataset, X Series, Y Series... 3.Set the image to the plot background 4.Click "OK"
Actual Result 1.Data set binding is lost.
Expected Result 1.Data set can word correctly. When exception thrown from the chart dialog message loop internally, the loop will be broken, but the state is not well handled, so abnormal behavior caused. added code to handle these cases.
The bug has fixed

Bug.Summery: core XMLValidator.addValidationMessage(XMLValidationInfo, IOException) needs rework
Bug.WithStack:
In tracking down odd validator messages, I stumbled across this method:
protected void addValidationMessage(XMLValidationInfo valinfo, IOException exception) { String messageStr = exception.getMessage(); Throwable cause = exception.getCause(); while(messageStr == null && cause != null){ cause = exception.getCause(); if(cause != null){ messageStr = cause.getMessage(); } } . . .
If the original IOException has a "cause" but that cause has no message, an infinite loop will occur because the "cause" local variable can never become null within the while loop.
The handling of the exception and cause objects further down is also causing strange validation messages. For instance, an inability to download the a system referenced DTD such as http://java.sun.com/j2ee/dtds/web-jsptaglibrary_1_1.dtd results in a validation marker with just "http://java.sun.com/j2ee/dtds/web-jsptaglibrary_1_1.dtd" as the error's message. In light of "out of the box" experience for disconnected users, see Bug 104413, we might want to consider fixing this for RC2 if simple and safe.
Created attachment 25106 suggested patch for org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.validation.XMLValidator Lawrence, I believe you're familiar with this particular chunk of code. Nitin, thanks for the patch. I've incorporated it into a fix for bug 104413.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 104413 *** Marking as verified just to signify correctly categorized.
closing

If the original IOException has a "cause" but that cause has no message, an infinite loop will occur because the "cause" local variable can never become null within the while loop.
The handling of the exception and cause objects further down is also causing strange validation messages. For instance, an inability to download the a system referenced DTD such as http://java.sun.com/j2ee/dtds/web-jsptaglibrary_1_1.dtd results in a validation marker with just "http://java.sun.com/j2ee/dtds/web-jsptaglibrary_1_1.dtd" as the error's message. In light of "out of the box" experience for disconnected users, see Bug 104413, we might want to consider fixing this for RC2 if simple and safe.

Bug.Summery: Caching Remote Resources Job hangs around
Bug.WithStack:
The remote resources cache starts a Job when the cache plugin is loaded. Currently the Job keeps running by rescheduling itself to run once per hour.
This isn't necessary, is it? The Job can be scheduled for the first time when a lookup is required and should be allowed to be unscheduled when it's not being used any more. Am I not missing the reasoning behind the rescheduling? Nitin, you're right. This is something I just hadn't got around to fixing. I'll fix this post 0.7 so the job is only scheduled if there are resources that could not be cached. I've modified the cache to only schedule a job when there are resources to cache. There will only be resources to cache when the resources were previously requested and the cache was unable to cache them for some reason (such as no internet connectivity).
This fix has been released on 20060412 for WTP 1.5M6. Verified in WTP 1.5 RC5a Closing bug.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The remote resources cache starts a Job when the cache plugin is loaded. Currently the Job keeps running by rescheduling itself to run once per hour.
This isn't necessary, is it? The Job can be scheduled for the first time when a lookup is required and should be allowed to be unscheduled when it's not being used any more. Am I not missing the reasoning behind the rescheduling? Nitin, you're right. This is something I just hadn't got around to fixing. I'll fix this post 0.7 so the job is only scheduled if there are resources that could not be cached. I've modified the cache to only schedule a job when there are resources to cache. There will only be resources to cache when the resources were previously requested and the cache was unable to cache them for some reason (such as no internet connectivity).
This fix has been released on 20060412 for WTP 1.5M6. Verified in WTP 1.5 RC5a Closing bug.

org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java:783) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager.notify(NotificationManager.java:270) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager.handleEvent(NotificationManager.java:242) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.broadcastEvent(Workspace.java:195) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Project.close(Project.java:171) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.CloseResourceAction.invokeOperation(CloseResourceAction.java:169) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceAction.execute(WorkspaceAction.java:133) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceAction$2.runInWorkspace(WorkspaceAction.java:424) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:76) Hi - Are you adding a Job rule with the specific projects? Looks like jdt is using the workspace root, so this rule may need to include that. Chuck, I am not sure why you assigned this to me. Did you mean to assign it to Nitin? Looking at the stack again... do we want to open this against jdt?
The platform is in the middle of a close resource action, and the container is just calling: JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() - which gets the rule conflict.
Not sure why this should be illegal.
I'll move to jdt. Looking at the stack again... do we want to open this against jdt?
The platform is in the middle of a close resource action, and the container is just calling: JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() - which gets the rule conflict.
Not sure why this should be illegal.
I'll move to jdt. Moving to Platform/Resources. Closing a project uses a project-level scheduling rule. The call to JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() can actually modify resources, and in order to do that it uses the workspace root as the scheduling rule (and it has to). One cannot try to begin a rule that is more comprehensive than the current rule. Thus, calling that method from a resource change listener is not safe. Also, doing so from a PRE_CLOSE resource change listener is not valid either. A similar issue in PDE: bug 94435. Looks like the jdt team will consider a fix in 3.2....
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 94764 *** Bug 94764 is in Platform/Resources, not JDT, and is only about improving error reporting, so this problem will still occur even if that bug is fixed.
It is wrong to call JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() from a PRE_CLOSE resource change listener, because it may create resources, and you are not allowed to do so from this type of resource change listener. Ok Kostantin, looks like this is back to you again...
JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() can't be called on the PRE_CLOSE event, so maybe listen for this in your FlexibleProjectContainer$Listener class? Thanks for doing the legwork to investigate this. I committed the fix. Haven't released it as there are other changes in the plugin. This may or may not be in RC1. Can't reproduce on 1.0rc4

Also, doing so from a PRE_CLOSE resource change listener is not valid either. A similar issue in PDE: bug 94435. Looks like the jdt team will consider a fix in 3.2....
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 94764 *** Bug 94764 is in Platform/Resources, not JDT, and is only about improving error reporting, so this problem will still occur even if that bug is fixed.
It is wrong to call JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() from a PRE_CLOSE resource change listener, because it may create resources, and you are not allowed to do so from this type of resource change listener. Ok Kostantin, looks like this is back to you again...
JavaCore.getClasspathContainer() can't be called on the PRE_CLOSE event, so maybe listen for this in your FlexibleProjectContainer$Listener class? Thanks for doing the legwork to investigate this. I committed the fix. Haven't released it as there are other changes in the plugin. This may or may not be in RC1. Can't reproduce on 1.0rc4

Bug.Summery: Provides way to set valid state of element
Bug.WithStack: A parsing valid element can be invalid from then view of user. For example, a datasource with a invalid connection string is valid by parsing but it not valid for user. Need Design engin provides new API to set valid state of element base on the custom logics. One design rule for ROM is that the design won't store the design state of the report. It's the DE's application's responsibility to check/maintain the design's state. Verified in build 20051220. DE will check/maintain the design's state
Bug.WithOutStack: A parsing valid element can be invalid from then view of user. For example, a datasource with a invalid connection string is valid by parsing but it not valid for user. Need Design engin provides new API to set valid state of element base on the custom logics. One design rule for ROM is that the design won't store the design state of the report. It's the DE's application's responsibility to check/maintain the design's state. Verified in build 20051220. DE will check/maintain the design's state

Bug.Summery: [api] editing model for org.eclipse.text

Lines.Line: - compound changes (which are important not just for undo)
- patch documents: recording a minimal edit script while freely modifying a
document. The underlying document is not changed until the script is applied,
but one can get a 'patched' view of what the document would look like if it were.

Bug.WithStack:
Investigation item:
It might be worth thinking about whether o.e.text needs a UI agnostic *editing model* besides the already existing *text model* (IDocument) - it would offer services currently managed by the viewer but really not depending on the presentation. Things that come to my mind:
- compound changes (which are important not just for undo) - undo (IRewriteTarget) - find/replace (IFindReplaceTarget) - patch documents: recording a minimal edit script while freely modifying a document. The underlying document is not changed until the script is applied, but one can get a 'patched' view of what the document would look like if it were.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Investigation item:
It might be worth thinking about whether o.e.text needs a UI agnostic *editing model* besides the already existing *text model* (IDocument) - it would offer services currently managed by the viewer but really not depending on the presentation. Things that come to my mind:
- compound changes (which are important not just for undo) - undo (IRewriteTarget) - find/replace (IFindReplaceTarget) - patch documents: recording a minimal edit script while freely modifying a document. The underlying document is not changed until the script is applied, but one can get a 'patched' view of what the document would look like if it were.

Bug.Summery: If parameter or parameter group name is "<", it is displayed as "lt;" in parameter dialog.
Bug.WithStack:
Description: If parameter or parameter group name is "<", it is displayed as "lt;" in parameter dialog.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a parameter named "<". 2. Preview. 3. Parameter dialog pops up.
Actual result: "lt;" appears instead of "<". parameter dialog uses "IScalarParameterDefn" to get parameter name. If you set the name to <, the getName() method returns a "<". Is it expected? I have checked it, Engine never returns "<" if name set to "<". we can reproduce this bug on Designer. if we name parameter as "<", the design file should be written as <scalar- parameter name="&lt;">. we should not write design file directly as <scalar-parameter name="<"> to reproduce this bug. This bug exists in paramter dialog, while not exist in parameter pane, so the value returns from engine is correct.
Created attachment 25117 screen shot Created attachment 25118 design file *** Bug 105110 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** escape the '&' Verified in build 20051014.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Description: If parameter or parameter group name is "<", it is displayed as "lt;" in parameter dialog.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a parameter named "<". 2. Preview. 3. Parameter dialog pops up.
Actual result: "lt;" appears instead of "<". parameter dialog uses "IScalarParameterDefn" to get parameter name. If you set the name to <, the getName() method returns a "<". Is it expected? I have checked it, Engine never returns "<" if name set to "<". we can reproduce this bug on Designer. if we name parameter as "<", the design file should be written as <scalar- parameter name="&lt;">. we should not write design file directly as <scalar-parameter name="<"> to reproduce this bug. This bug exists in paramter dialog, while not exist in parameter pane, so the value returns from engine is correct.
Created attachment 25117 screen shot Created attachment 25118 design file *** Bug 105110 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** escape the '&' Verified in build 20051014.

Bug.Summery: Data values of Y-series cannot be displayed correctly

Lines.Line: 1. Invoke chart builder, Data -> Y-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set
2. Invoke chart builder, Data -> X-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set
Result: X-series can be formatted, values of Y-series became "null" in the

Bug.WithStack:
Steps to reproduce:
Insert a chart into layout, set Data of X-series as DateTime type, Data of Y- series as Number type.
1. Invoke chart builder, Data -> Y-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set format for Y-Series Result: Format doesn't work.
2. Invoke chart builder, Data -> X-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set format for X-series; Result: X-series can be formatted, values of Y-series became "null" in the layout.
3.1 Do the same with step 2 to X-series 3.2 Invoke chart builder, Attributes -> Y-series -> Data Point -> Orthogonal_Value -> 0.0# -> Set format for Y-series Result: Both X and Y series could be formatted correctly. Created attachment 25028 Design file for reproducing the bug Created attachment 25029 Error log in step 2 Created attachment 25030 Error log in step 2 When legend item type is "category", the x-series format specifier will be applied to both X,Y series. This is the expected behavior. The button design is not user-friendly.

Insert a chart into layout, set Data of X-series as DateTime type, Data of Y- series as Number type.
1. Invoke chart builder, Data -> Y-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set format for Y-Series Result: Format doesn't work.
2. Invoke chart builder, Data -> X-Series -> Data Definitions -> 0.0# -> Set format for X-series; Result: X-series can be formatted, values of Y-series became "null" in the layout.
3.1 Do the same with step 2 to X-series 3.2 Invoke chart builder, Attributes -> Y-series -> Data Point -> Orthogonal_Value -> 0.0# -> Set format for Y-series Result: Both X and Y series could be formatted correctly. Created attachment 25028 Design file for reproducing the bug Created attachment 25029 Error log in step 2 Created attachment 25030 Error log in step 2 When legend item type is "category", the x-series format specifier will be applied to both X,Y series. This is the expected behavior. The button design is not user-friendly.

Bug.Summery: Allow the separation of the testcase name and the test method.

Lines.Line: 1)Allow the separation of the testcase name and the test method.
This feature allows the user to call the same test method with
different test names and avoids unnecessary code being written.A good example
for this is a situation where one might have to run the same test on different
versions of the same product.Using this framework he would use the same test
method with different test names thus completing the tests.
The user can use the getTestMethodName() and setTestMethodName(String) to get
and set the test method. By default the test case name is the name of the test
In general if you are using the above feature you would expect to be
allowed to pass parameters to your test method. This is not allowed in regular
junit and has been added as a feature in DynamicTestCase. You will have the
flexibility to pass any number of parameters to your test method.

Bug.WithStack:
1)Allow the separation of the testcase name and the test method. This feature allows the user to call the same test method with different test names and avoids unnecessary code being written.A good example for this is a situation where one might have to run the same test on different versions of the same product.Using this framework he would use the same test method with different test names thus completing the tests.
The user can use the getTestMethodName() and setTestMethodName(String) to get and set the test method. By default the test case name is the name of the test method.
2)Allow test methods to have parameters. In general if you are using the above feature you would expect to be allowed to pass parameters to your test method. This is not allowed in regular junit and has been added as a feature in DynamicTestCase. You will have the flexibility to pass any number of parameters to your test method.
The user can use the getParameter() and setParameter(Object[]) to get and set the parameters to your test method.
These two features add a lot of flexibility to the junit framework and will avoid duplication of reusable code.
There has to be UI support to allow the user to specify the test case name and test method to be called and link datapools for parameters.
I will also attach the code for doing the described operations that can be used. Created attachment 25031 Code and samples that show how things work....
You can use DynamicTestCase.java and IDynamicTest.java directly ... there are also some samples that can be used ...
If you think that this is a feature that can be included then you will have to come up with ways to specify the test methods and their parameters in the .testsuite files. :-) Maybe i should have opened separate features for the different items ... but couldnt figure out how to go about doin that ... if you need anything feel free to contact me :-) Updating target to future as requested by the PMC.

Bug.WithOutStack:
1)Allow the separation of the testcase name and the test method. This feature allows the user to call the same test method with different test names and avoids unnecessary code being written.A good example for this is a situation where one might have to run the same test on different versions of the same product.Using this framework he would use the same test method with different test names thus completing the tests.
The user can use the getTestMethodName() and setTestMethodName(String) to get and set the test method. By default the test case name is the name of the test method.
2)Allow test methods to have parameters. In general if you are using the above feature you would expect to be allowed to pass parameters to your test method. This is not allowed in regular junit and has been added as a feature in DynamicTestCase. You will have the flexibility to pass any number of parameters to your test method.
The user can use the getParameter() and setParameter(Object[]) to get and set the parameters to your test method.
These two features add a lot of flexibility to the junit framework and will avoid duplication of reusable code.
There has to be UI support to allow the user to specify the test case name and test method to be called and link datapools for parameters.

You can use DynamicTestCase.java and IDynamicTest.java directly ... there are also some samples that can be used ...

Bug.WithOutStack:
Hello, when creating JavaScript inside a JSP HTML page, Java variables definied in a for loop are not recognized in an embedded Java expression.
I'll attach a small example to this bug report that spits the error message "i cannot be resolved" although the page itsself renders fine. In the OpenMDX code, there are about 45 places that thrigger this wrong error message.
The interesting thing is that this is only triggered in the first occurence (inside the <script>-Tags, and not for the second one (that is in the body). Created attachment 25032 Test jsp file that triggers the error message Thanks the the sample file ... we need as many test cases as we can get. We'll look at problem and fix for 1.0 release.
Thanks. Can you reproduce it? Glad you asked ... no, I can not reproduce it. I tried on latest build (I 7/22) if you can reproduce it on latests builds, please re-open ... perhas with any other info that might help us to reproduce. (configuration file, or log file? ... available from Help About box).
Hello,
Maybe it is of importance that I open the file inside a "simple" java project, not inside a J2EE project. I just installed the WST via Help/Software Updates/ Find and Install into a rather unconfigured eclipse 3.1, and the i is marked with a red curly line.
I'll attach the zipped project directory, as well as my config files to this bug report.
The used versions (as shown from the Product Configuration page) are listed in the config.details I'll also attach. Created attachment 26102 config details
configuration Details copied from about dialogue Created attachment 26103 test project
This is the zipped minimal project directory that shows the bug. Mass transfer from pa to dw. Needs more triage.
This is not reproducible in 3.2 Per Ian's analysis, unreproducible in WTP 3.2.

Bug.Summery: [typing] Unable to save modified text

Lines.Line: - create a new file with 3 lines of text inside and save
- Undo Typing (the 2 deleted lines come back and the file can be saved)
- Delete the last line: here it is the bug => The file cannot be saved anymore !!

Bug.WithStack:
I have reproduced this bug on text editor and java editor.
Scenario: - create a new file with 3 lines of text inside and save - Delete the 2 last lines - Save - Undo Typing (the 2 deleted lines come back and the file can be saved) - Delete the last line: here it is the bug => The file cannot be saved anymore !!
For the scenario purpose, I start with a new file, but it works with an existing file.
This bug has been also reproduced on Eclipse3.1RC4 on Linux Debian as OS. Works for me using R3.1. Maybe I did some steps wrong, e.g. "Delete the last 2 lines" can be accomplished in many different ways ;-).
Please provide more detailed steps if you see this using R3.1 or newer. To delete a bunch of lines, I select them, and use the delete key. The 2 lines must be deleted at once.
If I use the "delete line" key, I am not reproducing the bug (the 2 lines are deleted independantly).
I produced also it on eclipse 3.1RC3 on windows XP (so, seems not to be linked to OS). 3.1RC3 is a release candidate and not R3.1. Did you see it on R3.1?
Can you provide selection and caret for each step, e.g. do you have
111 222 333<caret><eof>
or 111 222 333 <caret><eof> I produced the bug on eclipse 3.1 (final release) on linux debian. I also produced the bug on eclipse 3.1RC3 on windows XP.
It works with both your scenarii: This is the step I followed with the 1st scnenario
1) 111 222 333<caret><eof>
=> save
2) 111 <caret>222 333<eof>
with <caret> to <eof> selected => hit the delete key and save
3) 111 <caret><eof>
=> undo typing
4) 111 <caret>222 333<eof>
with <caret> to <eof> selected
5) 111 222 <caret>333<eof>
with <caret> to <eof> selected => hit the "delete" key
Bug: the file cannot be saved now
Hope you have enough data :)
The editor thinks the file is not dirty (no * in the tab). Looks like a modification stamp bug. Cannot reproduce with I20051222.
I believe this could be bug 109104 which is in 3.1 has been fixed in 3.1.1 and 3.2 M2. *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 109104 ***
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 109104 *** Verified on 3.1.1

Bug.Summery: [workspace] Ant compiler adapter doesn't respect compiler problem severity levels
Bug.WithStack:
It seems like when the Java compiler is called from within an Ant build file (as generated by the PDE), then the compiler does not respect the compiler problem severity levels configured in the preferences or at the project level.
So if I for instance in the preferences "Java > Compiler > Errors/Warnings" set the level of "Potential programming problems > Serializable class without serialVersionUID" to "Ignore" then I still get a warning when I compile the plugin project using the PDE generated Ant build.xml. This is a problem with the build script. Moving to PDE/Build PDE build is not workspace aware meaning that it will ignore all the project settings such as encoding, warning level, jre level, etc. pde.build will use the property javacWarnings.<libraryName> from the plugin's build.properties file.
This property should be a list of the kinds of warnings we want the compiler to report. ex: javacWarnings..= semicolon, syntheticAccess, nls
These are passed directly to the compiler using the commandline argument -warn Currently they are passed as "-warn:<warnings>" rather than "-warn:+<warnings>" which means the default warnings will still need to be listed.
We would need the pde.ui to write this information to the build.properties file re comment 3: these javacWarning.* keys are too advanced and require a complicated UI, which may not after all be better than the source page. They do not warrant adding them to the Build page of the editor.
The user can always use the source page.
Proper pde/build documentation of this key should be enough Bug 123597 covers the documentation of these properties *** Bug 76218 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.WithStack:
3.1, dual-processor machine
I tried to start eclipse with an existing workspace, but it wouldn't show the workbench window after having shown the startup progress dialog. The CPU is at 100%, which indicates that both processors are under heavy load.
Stacktraces look like the one below.
I'm not sure whether JDT/Core is the right component for this bug. But I assume that classpath containers should not be initialized concurrently.

Wassim - could it loop indefinitely ? After killing the vm and restarting, it hung again with the same stacktrace. After killing again and restarting again, I was not able to reproduce any more (I did several shutdown/restart cycles, which all went well). I made a change to how access to the HashMaps is synchronized. Reopen, if you can still reproduce in the coming builds. I noticed a fix was already reported in bug 103410 and fix applied to head and 3.1.1 streams. I will mark this as duplicate. Marking as duplicate, but merging the additional fix into 3.1.1 stream, because the hash maps are static, so the synchronization should be on the class.

Bug.WithOutStack:
3.1, dual-processor machine
I tried to start eclipse with an existing workspace, but it wouldn't show the workbench window after having shown the startup progress dialog. The CPU is at 100%, which indicates that both processors are under heavy load.
Stacktraces look like the one below.
I'm not sure whether JDT/Core is the right component for this bug. But I assume that classpath containers should not be initialized concurrently.

Bug.Summery: Y Axis Markers, anchor can not take effort.

Lines.Line: 2.Edit the Y Axis Markers, Set Anchor to East

Bug.WithStack:
Steps: 1.Create a chart 2.Edit the Y Axis Markers, Set Anchor to East
Actual Result 1.Preview, anchor can not take effort
Expected Result: 1.Preview, anchor is east. Fixed. The bug has fixed
Bug.WithOutStack:
Steps: 1.Create a chart 2.Edit the Y Axis Markers, Set Anchor to East
Actual Result 1.Preview, anchor can not take effort
Expected Result: 1.Preview, anchor is east. Fixed. The bug has fixed

Bug.Summery: Can not delete driver in manage drivers

Lines.Line: 1.Create a new report, in the data explorer view, new a datasource, select
JDBC Data Source, click Next button. Click "Manage Drivers...", delete the
listed JAR files. Then click "OK", in the New Data Source dialog,
2.Create a new datasource, open the manager dirvers, you will see the deleted
JAR file is still on the list.

Bug.WithStack: 1.Create a new report, in the data explorer view, new a datasource, select JDBC Data Source, click Next button. Click "Manage Drivers...", delete the listed JAR files. Then click "OK", in the New Data Source dialog, click "Cancel". 2.Create a new datasource, open the manager dirvers, you will see the deleted JAR file is still on the list. fixed The bug fixed
Bug.WithOutStack: 1.Create a new report, in the data explorer view, new a datasource, select JDBC Data Source, click Next button. Click "Manage Drivers...", delete the listed JAR files. Then click "OK", in the New Data Source dialog, click "Cancel". 2.Create a new datasource, open the manager dirvers, you will see the deleted JAR file is still on the list. fixed The bug fixed

Bug.Summery: [Improve Page Break Management] Show header on first, Floating footer don't work in Master Page

Lines.Line: 1. New a project and a report
2. Click Master Page icon in Layout view to shift to Master page view
3. Add AutoText items in header and footer in master page
4. In Property Editor- Master Page tab, select Header/Footer
5. Select Show header on first; Show footer on last; Floating footer

Bug.WithStack:
The Steps of Reproduce: 1. New a project and a report 2. Click Master Page icon in Layout view to shift to Master page view 3. Add AutoText items in header and footer in master page 4. In Property Editor- Master Page tab, select Header/Footer 5. Select Show header on first; Show footer on last; Floating footer
Expected Result: Show header on first; Show footer on last; Floating footer should work.
Actual Result: Show header on first; Show footer on last; Floating footer don't work. floating footer is not support in 1.0.1, so move it to BIRT 2.0 *** Bug 109587 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 120819 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** support show-header-on-first, show-footer-on-last in RenderTask, but it is still not supported in RunAndRenderTask. *** Bug 123517 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 123534 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Now PDF emitter supports floating footer Floating footer: supported in PDF Show header on First: support in all formats Show footer on last: support in PDF and RenderTask in HTML.
*** Bug 154219 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** please verify these engine option works. *** Bug 218131 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Show header on First/Show footer on Last: supported in all formats
Floating footer: supported in HTML defer to future to support PDF/PS defer to 2.5.0 defer to RC1 due to resource limitation. defer to 2.5.1 as those issues only exist in runAndRender task. The result of run then render is correct. schedule to 2.6 to allow more time to work on this enhancement.

Bug.Summery: Dataset refresh problem

Lines.Line: 1.Create a datasource, dataset. Then move the related driver to a new path,
the dataset will be invalid. That's ok.
2.Then correct the driver path in the "Manage Drivers..." dialog. It seems
that the dataset is still invalid, but actually the preview result and some
other data function is ok. I found until you click the "Data Source" tab in
the "Edit Data Set" dialog, the dataset is changed to valid.
User can add a driver from "Manage JDBC Driver",then the Dataset will become
valid,do not need to switch to "Data Source" Page any more.

Bug.WithStack: 1.Create a datasource, dataset. Then move the related driver to a new path, the dataset will be invalid. That's ok. 2.Then correct the driver path in the "Manage Drivers..." dialog. It seems that the dataset is still invalid, but actually the preview result and some other data function is ok. I found until you click the "Data Source" tab in the "Edit Data Set" dialog, the dataset is changed to valid. It works fine now. User can add a driver from "Manage JDBC Driver",then the Dataset will become valid,do not need to switch to "Data Source" Page any more. It works in 20050817's build.
Bug.WithOutStack: 1.Create a datasource, dataset. Then move the related driver to a new path, the dataset will be invalid. That's ok. 2.Then correct the driver path in the "Manage Drivers..." dialog. It seems that the dataset is still invalid, but actually the preview result and some other data function is ok. I found until you click the "Data Source" tab in the "Edit Data Set" dialog, the dataset is changed to valid. It works fine now. User can add a driver from "Manage JDBC Driver",then the Dataset will become valid,do not need to switch to "Data Source" Page any more. It works in 20050817's build.

Bug.Summery: Different display way between PDF and HTML
Bug.WithStack:
1.Insert a grid to layout of designer, in the central cell of grid, insert a image, in html the iamge is aligned left, but in pdf the image is centered. In html, the image is show in the left of page instead of the cell. This is because PDF and HTML use different algorithms to handle columns without size.
Moved to 2.0 final as this needs to be evaluated based on the new PDF emitter. Fix it in new BIRT PDF emtiter Resolved. The image is alighed left of the contained cell.
Bug.WithOutStack:
1.Insert a grid to layout of designer, in the central cell of grid, insert a image, in html the iamge is aligned left, but in pdf the image is centered. In html, the image is show in the left of page instead of the cell. This is because PDF and HTML use different algorithms to handle columns without size.
Moved to 2.0 final as this needs to be evaluated based on the new PDF emitter. Fix it in new BIRT PDF emtiter Resolved. The image is alighed left of the contained cell.

Bug.Summery: ClassLoader returns an Enumeration of only the first instance of a resouce under OSGi
Bug.WithStack:
ClassLoader.getResources() should return all resources with the specified name. Under OSGi only the first resource found is returned. An Example:
If 2 bundles contain the same file "org/aspectj/aop.xml" for example and both export "org.aspectj" a 3rd bundle that requires both will only see one of the files. Created attachment 25035 Test case for this bug
This zip contains three projects. Unpack it into an OSGi workspace. Each bundle contains an aop.xml file, in the org.aspectj package.
The project org.resourceloader.test contains a junit test case which can be run to rest a fix to this bug. If the test case can see all three aop.xml files, it will pass. Otherwise it will fail. A fix has been released to the HEAD branch (this is for 3.2)
A fix has been released to the HEAD branch (fixed for 3.2) should backport fix to 3.1.1 Created attachment 25076 Proposed backport to R3_1_maintenance branch Thanks a lot for such a swift response on this fix - all now behaves exactly as I had hoped.
Bug.WithOutStack:
ClassLoader.getResources() should return all resources with the specified name. Under OSGi only the first resource found is returned. An Example:
If 2 bundles contain the same file "org/aspectj/aop.xml" for example and both export "org.aspectj" a 3rd bundle that requires both will only see one of the files. Created attachment 25035 Test case for this bug
This zip contains three projects. Unpack it into an OSGi workspace. Each bundle contains an aop.xml file, in the org.aspectj package.
The project org.resourceloader.test contains a junit test case which can be run to rest a fix to this bug. If the test case can see all three aop.xml files, it will pass. Otherwise it will fail. A fix has been released to the HEAD branch (this is for 3.2)
A fix has been released to the HEAD branch (fixed for 3.2) should backport fix to 3.1.1 Created attachment 25076 Proposed backport to R3_1_maintenance branch Thanks a lot for such a swift response on this fix - all now behaves exactly as I had hoped.

Bug.Summery: [variables] Additional detail formatter option, show format only as label

Lines.Line: a) What to display against the label
- DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
- DetailFormatter, or EclipseDefault if no DetailFormatter
b) What to display in the detail pane
- DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
1) Label: DetailFormatter, or Eclipse default if no DetailFormatter
DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
2) Label: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
(As you can see, it is quite difficult to express what these radio buttons do
effectively, and in fact I had to try the middle option to see what it actually
did. So there is, at least, a useability issue here...)
However, despite these options, there is no way to do what I want:
4) Label: DetailFormatter, or EclipseDefault if no DetailFormatter
- DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
- DetailFormatter, or EclipseDefault if no DetailFormatter
- DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter

Bug.WithStack:
Currently, the detail formatter preferences page allows detail formatters to be used in three ways 1) Label: DetailFormatter, or Eclipse default if no DetailFormatter DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
2) Label: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
3) Label: Eclipse default DetailPane: DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
(As you can see, it is quite difficult to express what these radio buttons do effectively, and in fact I had to try the middle option to see what it actually did. So there is, at least, a useability issue here...)
However, despite these options, there is no way to do what I want: 4) Label: DetailFormatter, or EclipseDefault if no DetailFormatter DetailPane: toString
Instead of just adding a fourth option to the dialog, I propose that the single set of radio buttons at the bottom is broken up into two sets: a) What to display against the label - EclipseDefault - toString - DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter - DetailFormatter, or EclipseDefault if no DetailFormatter
b) What to display in the detail pane - toString - DetailFormatter, or toString if no DetailFormatter
Note, that this may affect interaction with Structure formatters and create even more combinations, I haven't thought about that. Currently deferred
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 137927 ***

Bug.Summery: [build path] Warning message on Java Compiler page should link to Java Build Path as well
Bug.WithStack:
I20050627-1435 (3.1)
The warning message on the Java Compiler project properties page should link to Java Build Path as well. I suggest to replace the "Configure..." link by two links "Configure Installed JREs" and "Configure Build Path...".
The "Configure Build Path..." should just go to the Java Build Path page iff the page is a properties page. If it is in the main preferences, it should show the dialog to select a project for project-specific options. The second suggestion is probably not very useful. You don't want to go to all of the projects through the project list dialog.
added an additional link > 20051201 Verified using I20051213-0010

(2) "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application". A tutorial

references to include the new tutorial.
- A number of UI names were not accurate. For example, in the process of
opening the New Datapool wizard the "New > Test Artifact" option is now "New >
Test Element". Also, now "Datapool" is listed in the "Test Assets" folder
- The procedure claimed you can access the New Test Artifact dialog from the
file menu. This is no longer the case for the Test Element dialog. (Note: you
can however, access the New Datapool wizard directly using the file menu).

first create the datapool. In the current UI, the first datapool equivalence
class appears. I updated the related graphic.

information. The new example illustrates a CSV file with two equivalence
classes. (Note however, the import does not succeed with two equivalence
- The documentation claimed that the UI qualified row indeces using equivalence
class names (for example equivalenceClass1::0). With the new tabbed view, this
- The documentation claimed that if equivalence class names are NOT specified
in the CSV file, each row will be imported as belonging to a separate
equivalence class. This is no longer the case. All imported rows are grouped
Patch 2: "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application"
- A portion of the material is outdated as reported in the original posting.
- The section does not show the user how to set up the JUnit tests in the first
place. It only shows the user how to substitute values from a datapool into an
existing non-test application. A comment says "// Lines from test ommitted...",
but, from the context, it isn't really obvious what the test would look like.
- The application itself is too complicated. When we are trying to show our
TPTP test features, it is nice to work from a simple and generic application
(i.e. so the user focuses primarily on our technology).
- The example is based on someone who went to "www.amazon.com and searched for
a book named 'atonement'." ... In any case, the title "atonement" is probably
not suitable. (I hope the localizers don't try to translate it).
- The java.io import was missing for the File class.
- The following library import statement was missing:
- Other datapool libary paths were out of date (as noted in the initial
- An overview tutorial seems to be the right way to start off the test
- The tutorial shows you how to set up a simple "shopping cart" application,
create standard TPTP JUnit tests (using hard coded data values), and then
integrate a datapool using the datapool API.
- I updated the library names and paths in the tutorial (along with detailed
instructions to add them to the java build path using Eclipse).
- Note: an enhancement request (111517) has been issued for the wizard to add
- I added "Related tasks" and "Related concepts" links.
- Stay tuned for images related to this tutorial.
Patch 3: General review of other datapool sections
- Added a note to run the Agent Controller in the prerequisites section.
- Changed the procedure to run the tests as a TPTP test rather than a standard
- Fully qualified the File class as java.io.File.
Abdullah, I believe that the patch that you submitted for 111622 was built on

one. I think that this bugzilla was fixed at the same time as 111622 and so am
marking this FIXED. Please let me know if I misunderstood and need to make updates.
Yes, that's correct. The file submitted in the 111622 includes all the updates.
Sorry for not making this clear.

Bug.WithStack:
Datapool documentation is not current. The dependably section of the datapool documentation in TPTP 4.0 (200507141319 build) on accessing a datapool from a TPTP JUnit test (help/topic/org.eclipse.hyades.test.doc.user/tasks/taccessdp.htm) is not current for the following reasons: 1) Numerous references to Hyades. 2) Dependencies have since changed with the recent TPTP plug-in refactoring: [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.hyades.models.common_3.0.0/common_model.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.hyades.test.datapool_3.0.0/datapool_api.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.ecore_2.0.0/runtime/ecore.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.common_2.0.0/runtime/common.jar Also, consider fixing the formatting of the code samples. Consider reviewing the remaining TPTP documentation for similar problems as points 1 and 2. Reassigning to the default component owner as per email with Alex Nolan. Created attachment 27841 Patch 1: "Creating a datapool" topic I intend to submit this patch in four parts: (1) "Creating a datapool" topic. This topic includes/included many outdated components as described below. (2) "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application". A tutorial prepared as a replacement for the "Accessing a datapool from a Hyades test" topic. (I am just waiting to confirm a software defect before submitting this tutorial.) (4) Images related to parts 1 and 2. (3) General review of other datapool sections, including "Datapool structure", "Opening a datapool", and "Editing a datapool". Also, updating related references to include the new tutorial. ================================================= 104481 Patch Part 1: "Creating a datapool" topic ================================================= - A number of UI names were not accurate. For example, in the process of opening the New Datapool wizard the "New > Test Artifact" option is now "New > Test Element". Also, now "Datapool" is listed in the "Test Assets" folder rather than "Test Elements". - The procedure claimed you can access the New Test Artifact dialog from the file menu. This is no longer the case for the Test Element dialog. (Note: you can however, access the New Datapool wizard directly using the file menu). - The proecedure claimed that the Datapool overview pane appears after you first create the datapool. In the current UI, the first datapool equivalence class appears. I updated the related graphic. - I added a new graphic for the overview pane (I intend to attach it separately, with all other images related to this defect). - Added information about the CSV file structure, including equivalence class information. The new example illustrates a CSV file with two equivalence classes. (Note however, the import does not succeed with two equivalence classes > defect 111444.) - The documentation claimed that the UI qualified row indeces using equivalence class names (for example equivalenceClass1::0). With the new tabbed view, this is no longer the case. - The documentation claimed that if equivalence class names are NOT specified in the CSV file, each row will be imported as belonging to a separate equivalence class. This is no longer the case. All imported rows are grouped under a single equivalence class. Created attachment 27954 Patch 2: "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application" ======================================================================== 104481 Patch Part 2: "Tutorial - Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application". ======================================================================== Note: currently the tutorial does not work due to an assumed sofware defect (see 111622). If the software defect is confirmed and fixed, then this tutorial is complete as is (except for the final non-essential screen shot). If it turns out that there is a missing element or error in the tutorial, then this patch will be marked as obsolete and an additional patch submitted. Thus, it would be nice if bug 111622 can be resolved/rejected as soon as possible. ============================================================================ I developed a complete tutorial to replace the "Accessing a datapool from a Hyades test" section. Here is why replacing the section with a tutorial is a good idea: - A portion of the material is outdated as reported in the original posting. - The section does not show the user how to set up the JUnit tests in the first place. It only shows the user how to substitute values from a datapool into an existing non-test application. A comment says "// Lines from test ommitted...", but, from the context, it isn't really obvious what the test would look like. - The application itself is too complicated. When we are trying to show our TPTP test features, it is nice to work from a simple and generic application (i.e. so the user focuses primarily on our technology). - The example is based on someone who went to "www.amazon.com and searched for a book named 'atonement'." ... In any case, the title "atonement" is probably not suitable. (I hope the localizers don't try to translate it). - The java.io import was missing for the File class. - The following library import statement was missing: d:\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.0.jar - Other datapool libary paths were out of date (as noted in the initial posting). - An overview tutorial seems to be the right way to start off the test documentation. General tutorial notes: - The tutorial shows you how to set up a simple "shopping cart" application, create standard TPTP JUnit tests (using hard coded data values), and then integrate a datapool using the datapool API. - I updated the library names and paths in the tutorial (along with detailed instructions to add them to the java build path using Eclipse). - Note: an enhancement request (111517) has been issued for the wizard to add these libraries automatically. - I added "Related tasks" and "Related concepts" links. - Stay tuned for images related to this tutorial. Bug.WithOutStack:
Datapool documentation is not current. The dependably section of the datapool documentation in TPTP 4.0 (200507141319 build) on accessing a datapool from a TPTP JUnit test (help/topic/org.eclipse.hyades.test.doc.user/tasks/taccessdp.htm) is not current for the following reasons: 1) Numerous references to Hyades. 2) Dependencies have since changed with the recent TPTP plug-in refactoring: [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.hyades.models.common_3.0.0/common_model.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.hyades.test.datapool_3.0.0/datapool_api.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.ecore_2.0.0/runtime/ecore.jar [ECLIPSE_HOME]/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.common_2.0.0/runtime/common.jar Also, consider fixing the formatting of the code samples. Consider reviewing the remaining TPTP documentation for similar problems as points 1 and 2. Reassigning to the default component owner as per email with Alex Nolan. Created attachment 27841 Patch 1: "Creating a datapool" topic I intend to submit this patch in four parts: (1) "Creating a datapool" topic. This topic includes/included many outdated components as described below. (2) "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application". A tutorial prepared as a replacement for the "Accessing a datapool from a Hyades test" topic. (I am just waiting to confirm a software defect before submitting this tutorial.) (4) Images related to parts 1 and 2. (3) General review of other datapool sections, including "Datapool structure", "Opening a datapool", and "Editing a datapool". Also, updating related references to include the new tutorial. ================================================= 104481 Patch Part 1: "Creating a datapool" topic ================================================= - A number of UI names were not accurate. For example, in the process of opening the New Datapool wizard the "New > Test Artifact" option is now "New > Test Element". Also, now "Datapool" is listed in the "Test Assets" folder rather than "Test Elements". - The procedure claimed you can access the New Test Artifact dialog from the file menu. This is no longer the case for the Test Element dialog. (Note: you can however, access the New Datapool wizard directly using the file menu). - The proecedure claimed that the Datapool overview pane appears after you first create the datapool. In the current UI, the first datapool equivalence class appears. I updated the related graphic. - I added a new graphic for the overview pane (I intend to attach it separately, with all other images related to this defect). - Added information about the CSV file structure, including equivalence class information. The new example illustrates a CSV file with two equivalence classes. (Note however, the import does not succeed with two equivalence classes > defect 111444.) - The documentation claimed that the UI qualified row indeces using equivalence class names (for example equivalenceClass1::0). With the new tabbed view, this is no longer the case. - The documentation claimed that if equivalence class names are NOT specified in the CSV file, each row will be imported as belonging to a separate equivalence class. This is no longer the case. All imported rows are grouped under a single equivalence class. Created attachment 27954 Patch 2: "Tutorial: Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application" ======================================================================== 104481 Patch Part 2: "Tutorial - Creating a datapool driven JUnit test application". ======================================================================== Note: currently the tutorial does not work due to an assumed sofware defect (see 111622). If the software defect is confirmed and fixed, then this tutorial is complete as is (except for the final non-essential screen shot). If it turns out that there is a missing element or error in the tutorial, then this patch will be marked as obsolete and an additional patch submitted. Thus, it would be nice if bug 111622 can be resolved/rejected as soon as possible. ============================================================================ I developed a complete tutorial to replace the "Accessing a datapool from a Hyades test" section. Here is why replacing the section with a tutorial is a good idea: - A portion of the material is outdated as reported in the original posting. - The section does not show the user how to set up the JUnit tests in the first place. It only shows the user how to substitute values from a datapool into an existing non-test application. A comment says "// Lines from test ommitted...", but, from the context, it isn't really obvious what the test would look like. - The application itself is too complicated. When we are trying to show our TPTP test features, it is nice to work from a simple and generic application (i.e. so the user focuses primarily on our technology). - The example is based on someone who went to "www.amazon.com and searched for a book named 'atonement'." ... In any case, the title "atonement" is probably not suitable. (I hope the localizers don't try to translate it). - The java.io import was missing for the File class. - The following library import statement was missing: d:\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.core.runtime_3.1.0.jar - Other datapool libary paths were out of date (as noted in the initial posting). - An overview tutorial seems to be the right way to start off the test documentation. General tutorial notes: - The tutorial shows you how to set up a simple "shopping cart" application, create standard TPTP JUnit tests (using hard coded data values), and then integrate a datapool using the datapool API. - I updated the library names and paths in the tutorial (along with detailed instructions to add them to the java build path using Eclipse). - Note: an enhancement request (111517) has been issued for the wizard to add these libraries automatically. - I added "Related tasks" and "Related concepts" links. - Stay tuned for images related to this tutorial. Created attachment 27955 Patch 3: Images for (1) and (2). Bug.Summery: [quick fix] Quick Fix "... never read" removes method invocation
Bug.WithStack:
Hi.
Some sample code
void func() { boolean bool = open(); }
In Eclipse 3.1 I get a warning for that : "bool is never read". The corresponding "Quick Fix" completely removes the line :-/ Very bad. It would be better if just the assignment to the variable bool would be deleted ...
void func() { open(); }
Cheers - Marcel. Moving to JDT/UI Technically, the behavior is correct, since the initializer belongs to the declaration, and the quick fix is called "Remove declaration of 'bool' and assignments without possible side effects".
However, I agree that the initializer should not be removed unless it's a constant expression. For complex initializers such as ... boolean bool = open() && open(); ..., this may however introduce syntax errors.
Hmm - syntax error ?
the quick fix says "remove declaration of ... and assignments without possible side effects"
in my example above
boolean bool = open();
the quick fix not only removes the assignment, it does ALSO remove the method invocation !
Agree ?
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 87522 ***
