Bug.Summery: Need API to get native system images for displaying filesystem

Lines.Line: If this feature is not supported on a certain platform the method should return

Bug.WithStack:
Please add API to get the system images for - specific drives, e.g. getImageData(drive) - folder e.g. getFolderIcon() - default file icon e.g. getDefaultFileIcon() If this feature is not supported on a certain platform the method should return null on that platform.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 64138 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Please add API to get the system images for - specific drives, e.g. getImageData(drive) - folder e.g. getFolderIcon() - default file icon e.g. getDefaultFileIcon() If this feature is not supported on a certain platform the method should return null on that platform.

Bug.WithStack:
Using Tomcat 5.5.9 on the 7/19 i-build; the server was running and I executed a "debug on server" command for a JSP that belonged to a dynamic web project already deployed to the server; as expected, it offered to restart in debugging mode but the shutdown hung. Hi Rob,
I couldn't reproduce with 5.5.9 or another version I tried. Can you reproduce every time, or is there something I might be missing? Just tried again and I was able to repro; some other odd things I'm seeing: -even when I stop the server I get a dialog asking me if I'd like "start in debug mode" due to the breakpoints in the workspace -when I execute a debug on server, I get both a "must restart in debugging mode" dialog following by the dialog that asks if I want to start in debug mode due to the breakpoints -when I killed my test eclipse I was left with a dialog indicating that it was waiting for the publish step to complete (no cancel or close on that dialog)
Need to redo this with tracing on for Tomcat..
OK, tracing didn't really clear anything up but it is successfully stopping and starting before it hangs (I'm assuming this is a deadlock involving the various IServerListeners and other threads that are created during server start - I'm going to have to debug the execution to figure out what's going on); externally stopping the Tomcat server broke the deadlock and allowed the debugging session to launch (although it failed since the server was terminated).
Probably won't be much help, but here's the tracing output (I've noted with a ***hang*** where it hung; that stack trace is one I included in an existing Trace call so ignore)

resource change -<- I am also having trouble reproducing this. I'm curious if there is anything in the dynamic web project beyond some simple "test" JSPs?
Tomcat has the "feature" of hanging during shutdown if a webapp doesn't fully clean itselft up. However, it takes a bit of effort to create a webapp that exhibits this behavior. Given the age and number of code changes since the bug was reported, I'm going to assume that this issue is no longer a problem. Though the hang actually occurred, I'm marking it as WORKSFORME to avoid implying that any changes were made to address this particular issue. If the issue resurfaces, a new bug report with new details would probably be appropriate. This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using Tomcat 5.5.9 on the 7/19 i-build; the server was running and I executed a "debug on server" command for a JSP that belonged to a dynamic web project already deployed to the server; as expected, it offered to restart in debugging mode but the shutdown hung. Hi Rob,
I couldn't reproduce with 5.5.9 or another version I tried. Can you reproduce every time, or is there something I might be missing? Just tried again and I was able to repro; some other odd things I'm seeing: -even when I stop the server I get a dialog asking me if I'd like "start in debug mode" due to the breakpoints in the workspace -when I execute a debug on server, I get both a "must restart in debugging mode" dialog following by the dialog that asks if I want to start in debug mode due to the breakpoints -when I killed my test eclipse I was left with a dialog indicating that it was waiting for the publish step to complete (no cancel or close on that dialog)
Need to redo this with tracing on for Tomcat..
OK, tracing didn't really clear anything up but it is successfully stopping and starting before it hangs (I'm assuming this is a deadlock involving the various IServerListeners and other threads that are created during server start - I'm going to have to debug the execution to figure out what's going on); externally stopping the Tomcat server broke the deadlock and allowed the debugging session to launch (although it failed since the server was terminated).
Probably won't be much help, but here's the tracing output (I've noted with a ***hang*** where it hung; that stack trace is one I included in an existing Trace call so ignore)

Tomcat has the "feature" of hanging during shutdown if a webapp doesn't fully clean itselft up. However, it takes a bit of effort to create a webapp that exhibits this behavior. Given the age and number of code changes since the bug was reported, I'm going to assume that this issue is no longer a problem. Though the hang actually occurred, I'm marking it as WORKSFORME to avoid implying that any changes were made to address this particular issue. If the issue resurfaces, a new bug report with new details would probably be appropriate. This is part of a mass update to close out all stale WTP bugs which are in the resolved state without an appropriate targeted version. If you feel this bug was closed inappropriately, please reopen.

Bug.Summery: [context] broaden composite contexts to suppor persistent composite contexts
Bug.WithStack: While associating context with tasks is useful, Mylar core has support for working with composite contexts (e.g. when multiple tasks are active). In order to support interaction modes that don't require on diligently activating/deactivating tasks, we should expose a better UI for working with these composite contexts. For example, all of the task contexts in a category could form a composite context that's always available via Open Type and content assist. These composite contexts will probably have a more coarse granularity, and be more closely releated to working sets. Done as part of context API clean up. Changes listed in porting guide. Global contexts are now supported ensuring that we can add facilities like those suggested in the description post 2.0. However, we do not currently have a driver for such a facility. Open Type already reverts to the workspace history open type so it works well enough when no task is active. Created attachment 68867 mylar/context/zip Heh. Those renamings broke my JIRA plugin. :-( I added instructions on the renames to the porting guide prior to committing. Let me know if you have any trouble with them.
Bug.WithOutStack: While associating context with tasks is useful, Mylar core has support for working with composite contexts (e.g. when multiple tasks are active). In order to support interaction modes that don't require on diligently activating/deactivating tasks, we should expose a better UI for working with these composite contexts. For example, all of the task contexts in a category could form a composite context that's always available via Open Type and content assist. These composite contexts will probably have a more coarse granularity, and be more closely releated to working sets. Done as part of context API clean up. Changes listed in porting guide. Global contexts are now supported ensuring that we can add facilities like those suggested in the description post 2.0. However, we do not currently have a driver for such a facility. Open Type already reverts to the workspace history open type so it works well enough when no task is active. Created attachment 68867 mylar/context/zip Heh. Those renamings broke my JIRA plugin. :-( I added instructions on the renames to the porting guide prior to committing. Let me know if you have any trouble with them.

Bug.Summery: Provide an action to run CBE validation in rule editor

Lines.Line: 1) It does schema validation on the GLA adapter file itself against the GLA
adapter schema files. This is done when configuring the adapter in the runtime.
When in the GLA editor this validation is done when the adapter file is saved
and also when it is run. In both cases errors found are shown in the Problems
view. Note, this schema validation is only done when eclipse is running with an
IBM JDK. The Sun JDK does support XML schema validation. I don't know what
the Sun XML validator is that Lennart mentioned.
2) In the GLA formatter component when it creates the CBE, it checks for all of
the mandatory CBE fields before returning the CBE. If the CBE is missing
mandatory fields, an error message is logged and the CBE is not returned. When
in the GLA editor the GLA formatter is only executed when the adapter file is
run and any missing CBE field errors found are displayed in the Problems view.

Bug.WithStack:
Today, user has to run the adapter before getting validation done.
There are two types of validation done by GLA runtime:
1) It does schema validation on the GLA adapter file itself against the GLA adapter schema files. This is done when configuring the adapter in the runtime. When in the GLA editor this validation is done when the adapter file is saved and also when it is run. In both cases errors found are shown in the Problems view. Note, this schema validation is only done when eclipse is running with an IBM JDK. The Sun JDK does support XML schema validation. I don't know what the Sun XML validator is that Lennart mentioned.
2) In the GLA formatter component when it creates the CBE, it checks for all of the mandatory CBE fields before returning the CBE. If the CBE is missing mandatory fields, an error message is logged and the CBE is not returned. When in the GLA editor the GLA formatter is only executed when the adapter file is run and any missing CBE field errors found are displayed in the Problems view.
The GLA runtime cannot perform any validation on the CBE's it generates until it tries to generate them during execution of the adapter. The GLA only knows about CBE's in the formatter and outputter components. Checking for the presence of rules for the mandatory CBE fields when the adapter is saved would have to be done by the GLA editor UI. It sounds like Lennart wants that kind of CBE validation. Please raise the priority to P2 Update component Candidate for 4.2 Adding myself to cc list so I will get notified when "Design Summary" section of the design document is completed. My comments in upper case:
In the GLA formatter component when it creates the CBE, it checks for all of the mandatory CBE fields before returning the CBE. If the CBE is missing mandatory fields, an error message is logged IN HGLA.LOG Here's the user comment:
Q: 3A1 (2) Could this be improved by TPTP bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=104487? A: Yes. CBE validation would improve this to a 3. If the GLA would then tell the user what to update, this could potentially score higher. (i.e., don't just say "CBE Validation failed" but bring the user to the exact field that failed, provide a recommendation on how to correct the error, and allow the user to correct.)
Here's the definition for 3A1:
Anticipates and prevents problems - Applications need to be operational for extended periods of time. To reduce downtime, offerings need to be self-healing where possible so problems don't interrupt operations.
fixed
A validate button is available on the Parser and parser subelements. The action validates the completeness of the parser subcomponents by validating the content against the cbe schema The following docs have been checked into HEAD (for the TPTP 4.2 release):
org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/concepts/cadapt.html org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/tcreatingadapt.html
As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

If the GLA would then tell the user what to update, this could potentially score higher. (i.e., don't just say "CBE Validation failed" but bring the user to the exact field that failed, provide a recommendation on how to correct the error, and allow the user to correct.)
Here's the definition for 3A1:
Anticipates and prevents problems - Applications need to be operational for extended periods of time. To reduce downtime, offerings need to be self-healing where possible so problems don't interrupt operations.
fixed
A validate button is available on the Parser and parser subelements. The action validates the completeness of the parser subcomponents by validating the content against the cbe schema The following docs have been checked into HEAD (for the TPTP 4.2 release):
org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/concepts/cadapt.html org.eclipse.tptp.monitoring.doc.isv/tasks/tcreatingadapt.html

Bug.Summery: breakpoint properties menu entry placement
Bug.WithStack: 3.1 everywhere else, Properties is the last entry in the menu. when I rightclick on a breakpoint, I expect the same. Now that space is occupied by the editor properties (useless here - if I want editor properties, I don't click on a breakpoint) and the breakpoint properties is pushed somewhere else, when it is awkward to find because it's contrary to expectations. Fixed. Renamed action to "Properties..." and moved to end of menu. Please verify, Samantha. verified.

Fixed. Renamed action to "Properties..." and moved to end of menu. Please verify, Samantha. verified.

Bug.Summery: [88960] The ability to export UML2 and execution flow diagrams
Bug.WithStack:
Similar to how statistics data can be exported to HTML files, TPTP should provide a mechanism for exporting UML2 figures and execution flow diagrams to a file. It'll be nice if these figures can be converted to JPEG format.
A TPTP user seemed to require this feature so that he could include the figures in his report. The message he posted on the newsgroup appears below:
"I use TPTP 3.2.0 to generate some UML2 and execution flow figures. I would like to use them in my report. How can I export them to some files? It seems I can only export the statistics data to a html file. But I can not export figures." - Weijian Fang Sequence diagram will be done under faeture 81204 Sub features of enhancements should be tracked as defects Sizing not done, but could be expensive The print (avaliable in 4.1) could provide a workaround by using the "print in a file" option usually availiable in printer driver. Moved to 4.2 for consideration. Bug.Summery: Inability to determine default editor by the content of file.
Bug.WithStack:
Current eclipse allows associating multiple editors to certain file name pattern, for example, Editor1 / Editor2 / Editor3 can be designated to edit "*.xml". However, there are cases that files with same naming pattern should be editted with different editors based on the file content. For example, "a.xml" may contain content that can be only understood by Editor1, hence, it should be only edited by Editor1 and Editor2 / Editor3 should not appear in the "Open with.." context menu.
Therefore, eclipse platform is required to provide some mechanism or extension point for Editor1 to parse the content of "a.xml" before platform associate the editor to "a.xml", in order to determine whether Editor1 is applicable to "a.xml". This feature is available in eclipse 3.1. You can now bind editors to content types as well as just file names and extensions. Bindings for content types may investigate the contents of the file if the content type extension specifies it.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Current eclipse allows associating multiple editors to certain file name pattern, for example, Editor1 / Editor2 / Editor3 can be designated to edit "*.xml". However, there are cases that files with same naming pattern should be editted with different editors based on the file content. For example, "a.xml" may contain content that can be only understood by Editor1, hence, it should be only edited by Editor1 and Editor2 / Editor3 should not appear in the "Open with.." context menu.
Therefore, eclipse platform is required to provide some mechanism or extension point for Editor1 to parse the content of "a.xml" before platform associate the editor to "a.xml", in order to determine whether Editor1 is applicable to "a.xml". This feature is available in eclipse 3.1. You can now bind editors to content types as well as just file names and extensions. Bindings for content types may investigate the contents of the file if the content type extension specifies it.

Bug.Summery: EAR Artifact Edit API should return arrays and not lists
Bug.WithStack:
EARArtifactEdit has getComponentReferences() and getJ2EEModules() each which return lists and not arrays. This should be switched before API is declared. This is fixed for the 0815 WTP M8 drivers.
Added test to EARArtifactEditTest, testGetJ2EEModuleReferences() to test API. Done.
Bug.WithOutStack:
EARArtifactEdit has getComponentReferences() and getJ2EEModules() each which return lists and not arrays. This should be switched before API is declared. This is fixed for the 0815 WTP M8 drivers.
Added test to EARArtifactEditTest, testGetJ2EEModuleReferences() to test API. Done.

Bug.Summery: [source manipulation] Constructor Using Fields should check all fields by default
[BIDI] Need to support Hebrew language code change to "he" from "iw"
Bug.WithStack:
In org.eclipse.ui.WorkbenchPlugin.checkCommandLineLocale() there is a check for Hebrew platform "iw". According to the following javadoc in the Locale class, it has been changed to "he" (with backward compatibility for "iw"). We need to add "he" as one of the languages we check for in this method.
http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/http/related/iso639.txt Added "he" to the list of RTL locales in WorkbenchPlugin. "iw" has to stay for backward compatibility. forgot to mark as resolved-fixed verified in I20060413-0010
Bug.WithOutStack:
In org.eclipse.ui.WorkbenchPlugin.checkCommandLineLocale() there is a check for Hebrew platform "iw". According to the following javadoc in the Locale class, it has been changed to "he" (with backward compatibility for "iw"). We need to add "he" as one of the languages we check for in this method.
http://www.ics.uci.edu/pub/ietf/http/related/iso639.txt Added "he" to the list of RTL locales in WorkbenchPlugin. "iw" has to stay for backward compatibility. forgot to mark as resolved-fixed verified in I20060413-0010

Bug.Summery: [discussion] automatic task activation

Lines.Line: 1) Task activation needs to do a more thorough restore of the UI, probably right down to maintaining editor locations. This may be possible with Eclipse's editor mementosl, but it would really help if they gave us bug 138666
2) Activation needs to become way faster. The above bug would take care of most of that. If we keep contexts zipped on disk that should take care of the time doing IO.
- you navigates to an element that is a landmark in another task context
- you're notified of the related contest by an in-place view (so that it's not
modal and won't stick if you ignore) which shows the current task and the task
- you now have the option of selecting the other task to have both active, or
onloy one of the two active

Bug.WithStack:
It would be an interesting and very handy feature if Mylar would authomatically switch active context, for example when user try to open or jump into some class that is already in a lanmark of some other non active task.
So, it would close unrelated editors and reopen those who hab been used with selected task. That should improve user experience with task list quite a lot.
I imagine button on a Mylar tasklist view that would activate this functionality, otherwise classes will be added to the current context. This is a very neat idea, and I really like the notion of using landmarks to determine when a programmer has switched contexts without specifying or realizing it.
It'll be hard to get the UI right to start with, but we can iterate by incorporate feedback and usage data. Let me know what you think of the following: - you navigates to an element that is a landmark in another task context - you're notified of the related contest by an in-place view (so that it's not modal and won't stick if you ignore) which shows the current task and the task (s) containing landmarks for that element - you now have the option of selecting the other task to have both active, or onloy one of the two active
Note that this will require Mylar core to support a large number of 'inactive' contexts that it can query, which is scheduled for 0.4 (August).
It also gives me another idea: what if we have an quick-key in-place popup that shows all the tasks contexts that you've had active, say in the past 5 days or something, sorted by time that each has been active (we keep track of that). That way switching between tasks should be as convenient as hitting Ctrl+E to toggle between editors. Think that would work? (In reply to comment #1) > This is a very neat idea, and I really like the notion of using landmarks to > determine when a programmer has switched contexts without specifying or > realizing it. > It'll be hard to get the UI right to start with, but we can iterate by > incorporate feedback and usage data. Let me know what you think of the > following: > - you navigates to an element that is a landmark in another task context > - you're notified of the related contest by an in-place view (so that it's not > modal and won't stick if you ignore) which shows the current task and the task > (s) containing landmarks for that element > - you now have the option of selecting the other task to have both active, or > onloy one of the two active > Note that this will require Mylar core to support a large number of 'inactive' > contexts that it can query, which is scheduled for 0.4 (August). > It also gives me another idea: what if we have an quick-key in-place popup > that shows all the tasks contexts that you've had active, say in the past 5 > days or something, sorted by time that each has been active (we keep track of > that). That way switching between tasks should be as convenient as hitting > Ctrl+E to toggle between editors. Think that would work?
I wonder if this will be too disruptive to the programmer to pop-up views, even if they are in-place. Some alternatives to consider might be to do so analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you might be able to delay until you are more sure. (In reply to comment #2) > I wonder if this will be too disruptive to the programmer to pop-up views, > even if they are in-place.
I totally agree!
That is actually I've suggested an easily accessible switch on task view that can activate task auto switching.
In a worst case user can just activate previous task again. You can probably provide a back/forward actions to simplify that.
I also don't think that quck switch view is really needed. You supposely have view all the time and it can be activated with Alt-Shift-Q or Ctrl-F7
> Some alternatives to consider might be to do so > analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts > overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of > overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely > complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the > programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there > is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context > speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably > still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you > might be able to delay until you are more sure.
It sounds too complicated ad as a result difficult to understand for an average user. Isn't it? > > Some alternatives to consider might be to do so > > analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts > > overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of > > overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely > > complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the > > programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there > > is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context > > speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably > > still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you > > might be able to delay until you are more sure. > It sounds too complicated ad as a result difficult to understand for an average > user. Isn't it?
Yup, its not simple, but not likely that complicated. Most of it would be hidden and its "success" would be only if it did the right thing a high proportion of the time and was somewhat obvious why it failed when it didn't.
What we need on the list (and this bug report provides) is a future enhancement for backing up on contexts so not matter what mechanism one can return to a previous point (although its not trivial to get a UI that allows one to specify "the right point").
Very interesting stuff! So it sounds like this should lean towards being more implicit (e.g. no popups), be explicit about working implicitly (e.g. with a button to indicate that automatic context switching is enabled), and also be loud enough so that when it's wrong the user can back out of the switch.
Eugene: personally I do always have the task list up, so don't see any need for a fast view either. And thanks to the filters I don't usually see a scrollbar in my task list. But even with just the explicit task switching support, I'm *really* starting to want the back/forward functionality that you suggest, and was tempted to add it a couple of weeks ago since we already have all the structure needed to make that work. Could you submit a seperate enhancement request for that?
Gail: in the long term I think you're hit the point on the head that this is about traversing through contexts, and related to this idea of rollback. On the bright side the core already has the pieces to support this, since it can roll-back a context to a given event (e.g. a task activation, dunno, as you say figuring out what the right points are will be hard). Also, while the core supports this, I think that making a good UI for it will be both very interesting and very hard. It immediately makes mething of timelines and navigation trees for representing this aggregate "workspace context" that's composed of task contexts and punctuated by implicit or explicit task context switches. Mik, do you want to reopen this discussion? What I would like is for us to try out the simplest thing first: automatically activating a task when a bug is opened. An enabler for this is that we no longer go to the server on open. What I think we need for this to work well is:
1) Task activation needs to do a more thorough restore of the UI, probably right down to maintaining editor locations. This may be possible with Eclipse's editor mementosl, but it would really help if they gave us bug 138666
2) Activation needs to become way faster. The above bug would take care of most of that. If we keep contexts zipped on disk that should take care of the time doing IO.
In order for us to start experimenting with this I'm bumping the priority of the long-standing bug 125938. Once we have some experience with this let's consider the implicit activation of tasks. It looks like a typo in above bug number. Stale.

That way switching between tasks should be as convenient as hitting > Ctrl+E to toggle between editors. Think that would work?
I wonder if this will be too disruptive to the programmer to pop-up views, even if they are in-place. Some alternatives to consider might be to do so analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you might be able to delay until you are more sure. (In reply to comment #2) > I wonder if this will be too disruptive to the programmer to pop-up views, > even if they are in-place.
I totally agree!
That is actually I've suggested an easily accessible switch on task view that can activate task auto switching.
In a worst case user can just activate previous task again. You can probably provide a back/forward actions to simplify that.
I also don't think that quck switch view is really needed. You supposely have view all the time and it can be activated with Alt-Shift-Q or Ctrl-F7
> Some alternatives to consider might be to do so > analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts > overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of > overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely > complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the > programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there > is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context > speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably > still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you > might be able to delay until you are more sure.
It sounds too complicated ad as a result difficult to understand for an average user. Isn't it? > > Some alternatives to consider might be to do so > > analysis in the background to determine the possibility that two contexts > > overlap. If the programmer moves to a different context with low likelihood of > > overlap, just switch to the other task automatically. Another approach (likely > > complementary) would be to use dependencies to predict which contexts the > > programmer means as they navigate to some place in a project and then if there > > is more than one possibility to add the interactions to each possible context > > speculatively, backing out of ones that become less likely. You'd probably > > still need to gather info from the programmer about which is right, but you > > might be able to delay until you are more sure. > It sounds too complicated ad as a result difficult to understand for an average > user. Isn't it?
Yup, its not simple, but not likely that complicated. Most of it would be hidden and its "success" would be only if it did the right thing a high proportion of the time and was somewhat obvious why it failed when it didn't.
What we need on the list (and this bug report provides) is a future enhancement for backing up on contexts so not matter what mechanism one can return to a previous point (although its not trivial to get a UI that allows one to specify "the right point").
Very interesting stuff! So it sounds like this should lean towards being more implicit (e.g. no popups), be explicit about working implicitly (e.g. with a button to indicate that automatic context switching is enabled), and also be loud enough so that when it's wrong the user can back out of the switch.
Eugene: personally I do always have the task list up, so don't see any need for a fast view either. And thanks to the filters I don't usually see a scrollbar in my task list. But even with just the explicit task switching support, I'm *really* starting to want the back/forward functionality that you suggest, and was tempted to add it a couple of weeks ago since we already have all the structure needed to make that work. Could you submit a seperate enhancement request for that?
Gail: in the long term I think you're hit the point on the head that this is about traversing through contexts, and related to this idea of rollback. On the bright side the core already has the pieces to support this, since it can roll-back a context to a given event (e.g. a task activation, dunno, as you say figuring out what the right points are will be hard). Also, while the core supports this, I think that making a good UI for it will be both very interesting and very hard. It immediately makes mething of timelines and navigation trees for representing this aggregate "workspace context" that's composed of task contexts and punctuated by implicit or explicit task context switches. Mik, do you want to reopen this discussion? What I would like is for us to try out the simplest thing first: automatically activating a task when a bug is opened. An enabler for this is that we no longer go to the server on open. What I think we need for this to work well is:
1) Task activation needs to do a more thorough restore of the UI, probably right down to maintaining editor locations. This may be possible with Eclipse's editor mementosl, but it would really help if they gave us bug 138666
2) Activation needs to become way faster. The above bug would take care of most of that. If we keep contexts zipped on disk that should take care of the time doing IO.
In order for us to start experimenting with this I'm bumping the priority of the long-standing bug 125938. Once we have some experience with this let's consider the implicit activation of tasks. It looks like a typo in above bug number. Stale.
